author: {'steamid': '76561198074339983', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 7086, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7086, 'last_played': 1658953103}
review: This is a great oldschool RPG with plenty of interesting storylines and quests to pursue. It does get quite difficult on harder settings, so it can be a good challenge if that's what you're in the mood for.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030533981', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 12314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12314, 'last_played': 1657840862}
review: A fantastic old-school RPG. Just about the only thing that would make it better would be scroll bars that work with the mouse wheel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084002243', 'num_games_owned': 1003, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 3689, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1205, 'last_played': 1658918151}
review:
Старомодная, неказистая, но весьма атмосферная RPG в духе прошлых лет , да ещё и в открытом мире. 

Замес вполне прост - вы изгнанники, которых приговорили гнить в огромном подземелье, но тем не менее когда вы попадаете в этот подземный континент, то понимаете, что жизнь, пусть и жестокая, тут не просто есть, а кипит и бурлит. Если отбросить невыразительную невнятную графику, очень скудный звук, а дать волю воображению, вчитываться в тексты, выполнять квесты и исследовать мир - то совсем скоро вы перестанете обращать внимания на минусы визуала. Мир действительно ОГРОМНЫЙ, карта большая, и пускай почти все города это квадратные области с несколькими домами, поверьте, почти каждый город уникален по-своему. Где-то шахтёрский городок, где жители вымазаны в саже, где-то нейтральная территория вполне себе враждующих рас, которые решили установить нейтралитет, где-то целый город дружелюбных пауков, дружелюбных ящеров и всё в таком духе. Я провел в игре не так много времени, но она действительно увлекает, хотя и стоит признать, нужно брать передышки, а то бывает надоедает.

Рекомендую любителям необычного лора, исследований и приключений, а так же пошаговых замесов. Ну и если вам по нраву старомодные RPG - добро пожаловать, вас затянет надолго. Если подумать, то у игры целых 6 частей...

author: {'steamid': '76561198098208694', 'num_games_owned': 287, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 609, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 609, 'last_played': 1657488287}
review:
Ich kann das Spiel leider aufgrund der immer nervtötend werdenden Gameplay-Elemente nicht weiter empfehlen. Die ersten Stunden macht das Spiel noch echt Spaß und die simplen Mechaniken erleichtern enorm den Einstieg. Allerdings fangen die Gegner nach ein paar Stunden an, nur so mit AoE CC Spells um sich zu werfen, sodass man mit Pech teilweise permanent gestunt oder gesnart wird.
Auch in der offenen Welt rennt man leider häufig in sehr offensichtliche Level-Barrieren, sodass das Spiel doch deutlich geradliniger abläuft, als es zunächst den Anschein hat. 
Gerade bei der Schwierigkeit werden die zu simplen Mechaniken dem Spiel zum Verhängnis, da man immer wieder gezwungen ist, Orte zurückzulassen, nur um an anderer Stelle zu leveln, da man die meisten Kämpfe nur durch reine Stats und nicht durch eine gute Strategie gewinnt.
Die Lore ist immerhin recht einfallsreich, allerdings ist die wirkliche Story nicht gerade tiefsinnig und interessant und so musste ich das Spiel leider nach knapp 10 Stunden abrechen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986406527', 'num_games_owned': 350, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 2131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1472, 'last_played': 1656950518}
review:
This is super dumbed down version of the original Avernum. It's so dumb that it feels unfinished with all those missing features.

but the story is mostly intact so you can still experience that, even if it feels like a museum exhibit. I'd still recommend getting the original from GoG over this.


...and yeah, visual upgrades are great and all but that shouldn't require butchering half of the game. Especially the ability to close a door. So much potential loot wasted. What a shame.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142856511', 'num_games_owned': 149, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 6068, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6068, 'last_played': 1655323240}
review:
I first played the original Avernum trilogy before I could read (especially not in English), just running around exploring and fighting. Now over 15 years later, I wanted to go on a nostalgia trip and see what the game was actually about... :P Though I mostly played Avernum 2 & 3 as a kid, so to be honest there wasn't that big of a dose of nostalgia involved with this installment.

[h1]Comparison to Avernum 1[/h1]
The first thing I have to say is that this new and improved version has [b]so much more[/b] quality of life fixes compared to Avernum 1: you don't have to keep track of quests by yourself in Notepad as there's an actual Journal in-game and you also don't have to identify every single piece of random magical loot you come upon. For these updates alone, I'd be ready to recommend this new and enhanced version. This new version also changes how some spells work and completely overhauls the skill system. All in all, even though it's different from the previous iteration, I'd say that it's easier to get into and more intuitive. One of my pet peeves though is that you [b]have[/b] to start combat when you see an enemy and can't just walk up to him and slap him with the first guy in your party.

The graphics – while still not state-of-the-art – are pleasant enough to look at and a huge upgrade from the original trilogy. Especially if you have never played any Avernum game before you won't even have the nostalgia factor, so I recommend sticking with this version over Avernum 1 (which is available on e.g. GOG, if you're interested)!

[h1]Avernum: Escape From the Pit[/h1]
The first part of the Avernum trilogy still holds up as a nice experience in 2022, around 27 years after the publishing of the original game. Combat is a big part of the game, as is reading lots and lots of text – as that's how information about the environment, characters and quests is delivered. Frankly, it's almost like playing tabletop D&D and getting descriptions from the DM (and as you'll also notice from some types of monsters present in the game as well)! So expect to be [b]reading[/b] a lot in Avernum!

When looking at the whole game, combat is quite decent. It's not exactly perfectly balanced though, as the start of the game can be very hard, while towards the end it gets very easy (especially on Normal difficulty) if you have a couple of decent spellcasters in your party. The skill trees are very flexible and allow you to also easily train your melee/ranged characters to do a bit of spell slingin' to help with healing, for example. It's also quite hard to make an unplayable character as long as you at least max out your main ability score. On Normal difficulty the game is quite well balanced once you get past the rough start – and it's quite fun.

The writing in the game is quite clever and fun. The world is completely open, and you can explore it in any order you wish – though tough enemies will bash in your skull if you stray too far at low levels. There are a variety of side quests to complete and instead of one main story there are three great quests that grant you a final end sequence – and a bonus one for completing all three. The story isn't anything [i]that special[/i], but it nicely introduces the world of Avernum to you, sets it up for the next games, and gives you an idea where to go next in the world (unless you're just running around exploring like me :] ).

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
If you love the old-school (C)RPG genre, you should definitely give this game a try and see if you like it! It's a fun break from more modern games while still giving a satisfying experience featuring both fun combat and lots of descriptions of the world and events in D&D-style. If your interest is piqued, Spiderweb Software also offers a bunch of similar games that continue the Avernum saga!

[b]8/10[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561197992128282', 'num_games_owned': 2083, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 3043, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3043, 'last_played': 1653172757}
review:
It's important to know that it's the remake of a remake:
 Exile -> Avernum 1 -> Avernum 1: Escape from the pit 
While this means progressively updated stuff, it's still OLD. Most of it's "problems" or limitations arise from the age. The other most annoying stuff is that there is no zoom, so you absolutely have to play at a by Today's standards very low (e.g.: 1280x800) resolution unless you have way better eyes than most of us.

Avernum: Escape From the Pit is a classic isometric RPG, more like Icewind Dale than Bladur's Gate, but fully indie: action, environment puzzles and a quite acceptable lore in the background, all this on an open world map that is oh so much larger than any of the abovementioned. While I did not find the lore as alluring as that of the BG series, it might be because I was a kid back then.

The games use their own system instead of a (modified) D&D, with a action point turn-based system. It can be somewhat abused in some places, and I really wish the exact point costs were more clear every time.

Controls are not the best due to isometric and figures being taller then their own squares, almost totally obscuring the one abive them. But there is numpad movement too.


There is also no voiceover. For almost literally anything. But hey, it runs on a toaster.

Battles can be punishing at times, even on lowest difficulty if you are not prepared enough. But in other places you can just DPS through "content".

author: {'steamid': '76561197969671212', 'num_games_owned': 665, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1652049221}
review:
A completely charming little turn-based open world fantasy CRPG set in a sprawling underground realm. Highly recommend trying this if you like retro or pixel CRPGs. 

Does absolutely nothing in groundbreaking fashion, everything about the game is just "decent", but that's the draw, it's consistently "not bad", at the same time as giving those addictive retro fantasy CRPG vibes (c'mon, we all know you need a fix!). Play it if you're looking for a deep, generic open world fantasy CRPG. The writing in it is pretty good and there's tons to explore. You have your basic RPG turn-based combat system, inventory with tons of variety of loot, the in-town/in-dungeon map you walk around in for the actual dungeon-crawling, and then the world map, which you can roam around in and find such towns and dungeons, similar to the way the original Fallout game was set up (although the world map stays in an isometric style, just kinda zoomed out, very neat, and totally appropriate). Absolutely phenomenal game design for what it is. The game is pretty intuitive - they did an amazing job with the tool-tips and descriptions. I didn't play a whole ton, as I just came to see what it was like and am not particularly in the mood for a retro pixel CRPG at the moment, but if I ever am I definitely know which series to come back to. I keep a few little games like this on my non-gaming laptop especially for rainy days.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970815344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 2417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2417, 'last_played': 1645975623}
review:
This game is an under rated masterpiece.

Very much a classic RPG, it will certainly scratch the itch for anyone who grew up playing old D&D games and early DOS / MAC titles in the same genre.

Positives include that the world is deep, has well developed lore and maps, with tons to explore and plenty of secrets to find. Music and city sounds are vibrant and bring a game with otherwise retro visuals to life.  The in game manual clarifies spells and stats well, and the game is easy to pick up. Combat is usually pretty fun with the occasional serious challenge. The difficulty is adjustable at any time so if its too hard its not like you lose out on the ability to complete the game. The concept of a completely underworld main map is cool, monsters are well designed and balanced for the most part, and the same can be said for spells. Story is well written and creative, characters too, and the game gives you plenty of meaningful options in regards to player choice.

My only complaints might be that this game some quirks,  and the challenges of using the quest log can be a bit of an annoyance. Some quests don't tell you that they're simply repeatable and don't provide function other than money, and if your usually the kind of player who is skilled at these games then you may find yourself being a bit overpowered by the 40 hour mark. I consider these complaints trivial and not negatively impactful of game play at large.

The asking price of 10$ is more than fair for the 60-80 hours of content you can get out of it. If your a fan of these style games, this is an absolute must play do-not-miss gem.

author: {'steamid': '76561199006103395', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 14950, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1257, 'last_played': 1698542997}
review: Excellent old school RPG.  Uses a point based system.

author: {'steamid': '76561198186530370', 'num_games_owned': 2632, 'num_reviews': 571, 'playtime_forever': 2375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2375, 'last_played': 1651555639}
review:
Is this 3rd gen version of Avernum 1 is worth buying and playing over the Avernum 1 2nd gen version which is part of the Avernum 1-6 compilation sold here on Steam.? I definitely think so. IMO, unlike Baldur's Gate Enhanced Edition, the differences between the two Avernum versions is significant enough to warrant an upgrade. The UI is totally overhauled, and the graphics are much more detailed and rich. The game is also huge - took me around 40-60 hours to beat. Playing most of the side quests can even add more time on, so yes there is great value in the game.

I love this game. I think the underground empire for exiles setting is unique and extremely interesting to me. Unlike a lot of other generic fantasy settings, I found myself identifying with the characters and thinking a lot about what I would do in their situation. The world is SO interactive and vast - lots of NPCs, Quests, side stories, choices to be made. In fact there are numerous endings based on important choices you make in the game that really define who you're characters are in the world. Big thumbs up from me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041325937', 'num_games_owned': 889, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 9139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9139, 'last_played': 1651290718}
review:
A near-masterpiece of an RPG. Somehow a game by a small team has more quality content than just about every other game out there. The writing especially is incredible; full of wonderfully vivid descriptions and creative setups.

There are essentially two games here too: the normal game, and the torment version. The torment version will have you planning out builds in advance, doing whatever you can to exploit the mechanics of the game, hoarding ever-so-valuable potions, and completing a quarter of a dungeon before reaching a difficulty wall that will force you to go do another quarter of a dungeon to level up so you can advance in the first one. My only complaints are that some of the battles in torment do feel just a tad unfair, even in the face of the rest of the game's brutally difficult content. Occasionally you'll be forced to reload a save 40 times in a row, praying for RNG to give you a specific outcome just so you can survive the first round of a fight. It's all good fun.

Overall, an incredible game. I'm floored by what such a small team can make.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140622478', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 30695, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23681, 'last_played': 1709964071}
review: Spiderweb Software has always made some incredible story-based RPGs and then Avernum series is one of my favorites. It's about a group of exiles sent into an underworld prison to die but end up serving a society and people called the Avernites. I won't get too into the story in this review but it's basically about your group trying to escape the underworld as well as saving Avernum. It's a very strong story and a fun turn-based RPG to play. Highly recommend it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197971261376', 'num_games_owned': 3857, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 2917, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2917, 'last_played': 1649651494}
review: A remake of a remake done quite well. The mechanics are simple, the quests are simple, but the turn-based combat is solid enough to carry it along. The world map exploration does a great job of making you feel like you are exploring a gigantic cave system. No real moral quandaries, just a simple RPG with a neat premise. Well worth the price of admission.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026951342', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1345, 'last_played': 1690544392}
review:
I've seen a lot of people refer to this as an 'old-fashioned' or 'old-school' role-playing game, but that goes back to the first release of its predecessor (Exile: Escape from the Pit; different but similar game, and mostly the same storyline) in the '90s, when it was aping the styles of games that went all the way back to the early '80s. I wouldn't say that was why it succeeded in finding an audience back then, nor would I say that is what makes it special now. What makes it [i]special[/i] is that it was developed in that style intentionally, with an eye and an understanding for all the things which its format allowed it to do and do well. And what it does is give you a large, strange, unknown world, full of dungeons (which are in turn full of traps, monsters, and the occasional exercise in problem-solving) and just enough story and context to make each one of them seem different, important and interesting. Encounters need enough thought to get through that your input as a player is important to the success (and survival) of your characters, but are not so involved that coming across them when they are not expected becomes a chore. There's a good, solid, enjoyable game here; solid mechanics laying the foundations for a genuine, straight-forward adventure, self-aware without needing to excuse its premise under layers of irony and deprecation. 
Some (mostly optional) parts of the game are more text-heavy and narratively involved, and if you enjoy these then Spiderweb & Vogel's other offerings will probably be even more up your alley. But Avernum itself (and the rest of its series) is very much an adventure at heart, and as long as you can derive some entertainment from maneuvring into position around a difficult enemy, or finding a lever that opens a secret passage in a brewery cellar which turns out to be full of [i]spooky ghosts[/i] - then this game has hours and hours of that to offer. And those hours pack a lot in - I have 22 hours on my time played as of this writing, and I honestly thought it would have been more; I'd got through a decent chunk of the first act/area of the game, and made a few inroads into the second.
The format of the game is an isometric turn-based role-playing game, where you control a party of four characters - so if you're a fan of that format, this is definitely worth checking out; if you're not, it doesn't do anything appreciably outside of that arena that might convince you - but if you're interested in the genre and are looking for a good example of what it's all about and why people like games like these in the first place, this one is a definite contender. And it's cheap for the amount of game you're getting, and how up-to-date it is in terms of modern comforts like auto-saves and properly scaling display resolutions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004668309', 'num_games_owned': 163, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3467, 'last_played': 1639733926}
review:
Avernum, or Exile when I first played it, has an inspired setting, great dialogue and storytelling, and fun combat. I played the whole game and finished all the win conditions just so I could get the full story of the game, and that's rare nowadays. To have given that much of a care about this game means that Spiderweb Software is still killin' it.

Pick this game up and give it a shot. If you complete it and love it, just buy the whole series. The story just gets better in the next two games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002156890', 'num_games_owned': 826, 'num_reviews': 309, 'playtime_forever': 367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1647765669}
review: As a modern RPG player, this game is exactly what it says on the tin. It doesn't lead you around by the nose, but its not opaque either. It's best parts are its elegant simplicity of the game mechanics, and its worst are just bits and pieces of polish and design that the game doesn't have, for obvious chronological reasons.

review: БУКВАЛЬНО ВСЁ ОЧЕНЬ МЕЛКО!!! Разработчик, просто жестокий гном с голубым дипломом Акулиста...

author: {'steamid': '76561198102656763', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3259, 'last_played': 1645767651}
review: I wish I could enjoy this game. The lore is quite interesting, I love the world building and dialogues. The gameplay however is unfortunately quite frustrating. If a battle is hard, it's because you're not the right level,  so come back a few level later and it will be easy, repeat. There's no real strategy involved, as soon as you're not the right level for a monster, there's little you can do. It often doesnt feel like a game but a chore that you suffer throught so you get to know the story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052978397', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 635, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 532, 'last_played': 1710590188}

author: {'steamid': '76561198000564041', 'num_games_owned': 926, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 1461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1461, 'last_played': 1639877240}
review:
24 hours (at the time of this review) is child's play in CRPG terms, and it's true that I haven't finished Avernum.  Yet.  However, I will report that those have been an extremely fun and comfy 24 hours and I would heartily recommend this game to any rpg fan.  Behind the simple visuals and big text boxes lies an immersive interesting world and robust but approachable gameplay, as largely-scoped and open-ended as any larger-budget game of this type.  

Developer Jeff Vogel has been in the indie rpg market for longer than many gamers have been alive, and while Avernum may not look sleek it bears the mark of a creator who has learned exactly what areas to refine for a specific audience... even if the UI isn't the sexiest, the sprites aren't the cleanest, the soundscape isn't the lushest, etc.  There's an intangible sense of approachability to Avernum that makes it easy to pick up and easy to stick with, and it exceeds even some genre classics in this regard.

It might look like a relic but it's as engaging and fresh as any fancier rpg I've played, and I definitely recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098145828', 'num_games_owned': 946, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1123, 'last_played': 1639792334}
review:
The fact that there's no manual, no proper explanation of basic stats, and no list of spells/effects is unforgivable. If you're going to release a remake, at least include proper documentation of the game's basic mechanics.

Avernum is an old school RPG made in a time before the customs of modern gaming. There are many outdated ideas and customs that make no sense. For example, upgraded boots/shields/cloaks can be sold to a merchant, but basic ones can't. Also, there's a finite amount of items and enemies in the world. Once those items and enemies are gone they are gone for good and no new ones will appear, unless a new game is created.

These antique mechanics were common way back in the 90s when the original games were made. This one has updated graphics and minor changes, but is missing fundamental pieces. If you love old school RPGs then there is some challenge and fun here, though you have to work unreasonably hard for it. For everyone else, leave this to the history books.

author: {'steamid': '76561198354753220', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 10539, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 969, 'last_played': 1669251694}
review: This is a beautiful 3D remake of the original 2D Exile: Escape From The Pit. If you like turn-based RPG's, this is for you :-) My only problem with the game is that your party is only viable if each member specializes in something. A Shaman is weak because s/he specializes in both melee and priest magic. This means they don't get strong enough in priest magic to cast mass heal and mass cure by the time you need it. You also have to have a sorcerer to be able to stun large numbers. My problem isn't the limited options for viability. My problem is that the developer provides useless options. I sunk many hours in this game only to reach a point where I'm not able to progress because I don't have mass cure and mass heal.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976761085', 'num_games_owned': 1207, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 3165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3165, 'last_played': 1638661676}
review:
This game ran smoothly for me on Linux using Proton with no tweaks.

This is a game for RPG fans who don't care about production values or anything - it's made by a very small, but reputable team so you aren't getting anything flashy, but you get a solid game that can get your monies worth.

I wouldn't say anything is spectacular (again it's not a AAA blockbuster type game), but I found it fun for the most part.  I found the difficulty just fine for the most part - there's a clear progression in enemy types (i.e. goblins to Nephil to Nephar to Slith to things like various demons and strong monsters) so you can usually can tell if you are ready for the next area by how easy it is to face certain enemies.

That said, there were times where some foes felt annoying - particularly bosses. They never felt hard to me as much as they just seemed like simple bullet sponges.  They were no threat as long as I had my protections up but it felt like it took needlessly long to kill them.  Eventually I reached a point (max level, good equipment) where nothing was a threat - like the final quests or dragons.  That said, I would rather the game get easy, but be quick than easy, but take forever (looking at you Divinity Original Sin 2...) or hard (though I'm not really a fan of hard games - at least at the end of a long journey when I'm ready to complete it.

I also found the game was a little too long in the sense that around 40ish hours was when things got easy, but there was still a lot to do for the ending quests which required annoying puzzles and a lot of running around the world (even if there was things like teleporation).

author: {'steamid': '76561197972355522', 'num_games_owned': 1810, 'num_reviews': 163, 'playtime_forever': 4279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4279, 'last_played': 1579126918}
review:
When I was a wee lad, I got the demo for Jeff Vogel’s Exile: Escape from the Pit on some magazine disc. Having never played a western RPG, I didn’t really have any frame of reference for it; I thought it was fascinating, but also inscrutable. Years later, I would learn that the Exile trilogy was one of the darlings of the small ‘90s indie scene, where a few brave souls tried to make a living by selling their games by mail. It’s ridiculously large and ambitious, the work of a young developer who doesn’t know how to say “no, that’s out of scope.”

Avernum: Escape from the Pit is the second remake of the original (2000’s Avernum being the first), and while the developer is much older and wiser, he tried to retain as much of the original content and design as possible, while making it more approachable for us modern players who don’t want to get locked out of winning or have to use a pen and paper to keep our own quest journal. Avernum is most famous for its titular setting, an underground realm of cast-offs from an ill-defined surface empire. It explores and models this world in great detail, and what the game lacks in memorable characters or an overarching plot, it more than makes up for in the joys of exploring and inhabiting that world. Along the way is a whole host of sidequests and locations, from the serious to the goofy, and a surprisingly complex structure of having three different main questlines with three different endings, which the character can pursue individually or collectively; I did all three, and one of them (involving a desperate assassination in the surface empire above) managed to deliver a remarkable amount of tension and drama in what was essentially a no-budget game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047420073', 'num_games_owned': 1143, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 10546, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10546, 'last_played': 1638545111}
review: Великолепная рпг. Та ситуация, когда разрабы вместо бесполезного графона и озвучки, вложились в сюжет. Именно так должен был выглядеть балудрс гейт по моим представлениям, но он не затянул, а вот авернум буквально засосал. Прошел на одном дыхании. У игры всего два минуса - мало заклинаний (по 20 на мага и приста, из которых в бою активно можно использовать где-то штук 6) и маленькая вариативность в прокачке.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119688777', 'num_games_owned': 308, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 3018, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3018, 'last_played': 1449775440}
review:
[h1]At-A-Glance:[/h1]
[b]Game type:[/b] Turn-based RPG
[b]Genre(s):[/b] Fantasy
[b]Art:[/b] Isometric 2D graphics with some 3D rendering
[b]Length:[/b] Long (30-50 hours)
[b]Pace:[/b] Slow-paced
[b]Tags:[/b] Great lore, old-school indie developer, remake/remaster
[b]Computer requirements:[/b] Low-end


[h1]Notes:[/h1]
[olist]
[*] This game is an updated graphical version of the original "Avernum" game. It supersedes the original in all ways.
[*] Excellent writing where it feels like your choices actually do impact the gameplay. You will see your impacts on the world.
[*] A good introduction to Spiderweb Software games. I recommend starting here and then moving into the "Geneforge" series - the first game of which got a similar remake/remaster in February 2021.
[*] I played this for approximately 50 hours to experience all endings and as much content as I was aware existed. (Alaskan winters get to you, dude.) While the game never felt its length during play, I was pretty burnt out toward the end. Though I reckon that's entirely my doing and not the game's fault.
[*] There are tons of ways to diversify your party, though the game certainly favors melee characters. That being said, I can't think of any point where I felt like I [i]had[/i] to have a certain character type to proceed in a mission.
[*] I ended up getting pretty invested in the lore - and I can usually ignore the writing of 90% of RPGs. Perhaps due to its old-school background, this game (as well as many Spiderweb games) has a flavor that's hard to pin down. Think of "RuneScape" circa 2002/2003 - and I mean that very positively.
[*] Interactions with towns and other environments will primarily take place through navigating menus and doing skill checks. This integration is rare in many modern RPGs - the one off the top of my head is "Sunless Sea".
[/olist]

author: {'steamid': '76561198006693175', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1634412513}
review:
This was the first game by Spiderweb Software that I purchased and it got me hooked. I now own all of their currently available games and have played through them all on "normal" difficulty (recently restarted Avernum on "hard"). 

1. These games work; I have not encountered a single bug or glitch in any of them. I thought I had found one in Avernum 2 but it turns out I needed to talk to a very specific person before I could turn in the object (a certain quest involved returning a certain tome to a certain powerful being).

2. Low system requirements: These games are mostly remakes of titles originally released in the mid-90s, so they have only received some minor GI and OS updates. Up until recently I played these games on a 2010 HP home office laptop (1.4 Ghz dual-core CPU; not meant for modern gaming)

3. Superbly written and edited: Not only do these games have unique locations and characters, rich dialogue, and deep world backstories; but, spelling and grammar errors are few and far between. 
NOTE: You will be reading EVERYTHING; there is NO voice acting, nor was there ever meant to be.

4. Common Game Mechanics: With the exception of the Geneforge series (which allows you to literally create your own creature followers), all Spiderweb games use the same easy-to-learn combat system and game mechanics. The games can also be played using mouse/keyboard only, or both (I think the game may also be available for phone/tablet).

5. Well-balanced: except for two of the three main "bosses" in Avernum 1 and one main "boss" in Geneforge 5, I found game play to be challenging enough to feel rewarding but not so much as to be frustrating; although sometimes, I would almost swear that "dungeon bosses" have more health than all other monsters in said dungeon combined.

6. Open-World: All Spiderweb games are "Open-World", allowing you to explore freely; although, monsters in certain areas are stronger/weaker than others (except for Queen's Wish)

7. Character Customisation: Visual customisation of characters is extremely limited. Skills, however, need not be limited by class; it is entirely possible to have a Berserker who can wield Arcane Magic or a Hedge Mage who is a master with Two-Handed Weapons. Originally this was penalized by having cross-classed skills cost more; but, I think an update three or four years ago removed this penalty. The Avadon series has a unique skill-tree for each class however.


Overall, my only regret was that I didn't purchase the games as a bundle (which would have saved me about $60)

author: {'steamid': '76561197997790211', 'num_games_owned': 113, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 693, 'last_played': 1636397102}
review: Spiderweb Software's games all share the same bones (and a lot of the same graphics assets) so if you like one you'll probably like them all. My first exposure was with Avadon: The Black Fortress. Compared to that, Avernum is a lot more open world, versus the clear storyline path of Avadon. Neither is better necessarily, it's just whatever you prefer at the time. My only real issue is that I had to fiddle with the resolution settings to get the graphics to look big enough for my older eyeballs. 1360x768 for my 1080p screen seems to be the sweet spot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016949531', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 5290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3959, 'last_played': 1633350521}
review:
I am not young.  I recently retired and have gobs of extra time to dump into my hobbies.  I really only have one though. 

I’ve spent years looking at this game from afar, never really giving it the time of day, thinking that it was just going to be a wall of text adventure, with tedious micromanaging of your party and with little excitement to be had.  How wrong I was.  This is a great game that fires on all cylinders.  Just don’t expect triple A polish.  That’s not what this game is about.  Avernum: Escape from the Pit is about exploration and good old-fashioned D&D inspired adventure.  This is old school for sure, but it is very approachable.  The writing is topnotch and the setting is superb. 

The lack of really any sort of a soundtrack does hurt the experience in the long run I think, but I was completely satisfied with listening to the lonely wind howling through the caverns and the forlorn drip from a distant stalactite for hours on end. 

Just as a side note, I’ve been using the Steam controller to play this and it works great.

review: A remake of the one that started it all, and while not quite my favourite (number 2 takes that one for me), this is still always great to return to, the feelings it evokes when exploring the caves as a first timer to an unknown land is fantastic.  The gameplay and plot are really enjoyable, and is a great entry into the series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198810993476', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 5349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5349, 'last_played': 1629572119}
review:
É um jogo incrível! Tenho quase 90 horas de jogo e ainda há muito a se fazer.

Pontos positivos: Muito texto, horas e horas de diversão e desafios (é um jogo difícil), muita exploração, é possível criar muitas builds diferentes, possui três finais (são três quests diferentes que carregam o peso de histórias principais (fiz 2 de 3), muitas side-quests.

Pontos negativos: O jogo está todo em inglês, muito texto (chega a ser cansativo e no final eu já não prestava tanta atenção), não possui trilha sonora e os sons são limitados (recomendo jogar enquanto ouve música), levei um tempo para me acostumar com os menus.

Comprei o jogo em promoção, foi uns 5 ou 6 reais e diria que foi uma das melhores compras que fiz na Steam. Não conhecia a série nem o desenvolvedor, há três jogos da série Avernum e já adquiri os outros dois também em promoção e estou de olho no Geneforge.

Virei fã de carteirinha.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979956321', 'num_games_owned': 800, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 2547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1678, 'last_played': 1632700685}
review:
A remake of one of the greatest, not to mention one of the first, roleplaying video games to hit the PC market. This game should be part of any RPG enthusiast's game collection. A tremendously rich world, well written and creative beyond it's years. No doubt the influence of many RPGs that came after it.

Be wary though, it uses old school RPG difficulty and level mechanics so don't be dismayed if something whoops your ass while playing. Instead, when you run into that often too hard boss, record the locations, and leave the area and go explore for a while. You'll soon return to find you are now an even match for the enemy that gave you troubles.

11/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198048228331', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1761, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 548, 'last_played': 1703729372}
review: The game is not only easy to get in to, but also fun to play. The controls are simple to use, the storyline is simply marvelous and the graphics are outstanding considering that Spiderweb Software is basically just Jeff Vogel, his wife and a few other people. If you have not played any Spiderweb games or are new to D&D type games, then I would suggest that you start with this game as it would be a great introduction for you.

review: Old style gaming, but has reasonable RPG enjoyment. I would like it to have more graphic fidelity/resolution in the NP/PC characters so you could see text descriptions correlate. Items in environment are difficult to see.  Probably should be a cheaper game to purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198166317502', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 11366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 900, 'last_played': 1701775769}
review:
If you played Exile: Escape from the Pit or it's sequels then this is a MUST BUY.

True to the vision of the original Exile series, Jeff Vogel's genius shines through this rework, and hits you with a powerful RPG world. 

Are the graphics amazing? Nope. Are they perfect for the world? YES. If you like immersive RPG single player experience, this unique and fun RPG is more than worth the price.

It's not an easy game, so set it to casual or normal difficulty until you get levels and gear.

BUY IT!

author: {'steamid': '76561198002513498', 'num_games_owned': 186, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 716, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 716, 'last_played': 1626018307}
review:
Не знаю почему, но мне игра не зашла... Я думал затянет хотя бы сюжетом, но игра как примитивна визуально, так и примитивна геймплейно... Первый день было интересно, второй день становилось скучно, в в третий день отпало всё желание играть. 

Балдур гейтс 1-2  я с удовольствием прошёл, а тут, не знаю, что то пошло не так, жалко, я всю трилогию купил.

author: {'steamid': '76561198392221151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 5861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5860, 'last_played': 1626642404}
review:
Fue un largo viaje (de varios años, en mi caso, ya que nunca pude completar Exile) pero lo terminé. Gracias al amigazo que me lo regaló.

Puede llegar a ser un poco tosca la jugabilidad de a ratos (sobre todo con la vista isométrica que, a mi parecer, no le beneficia tanto) y la falta de música es algo notable para estándares modernos. Aun así, el mundo que escribió Jeff Vogel y cómo eso se traduce en el juego en la exploración, el ir encontrando nuevos personajes, el poder tomar decisiones que afecten el progreso y cosas así, hizo que me enganche muchísimo desde el punto de vista narrativo. Sin dudas, ese es su punto más fuerte.

PD: No se pongan mal si se atoran en alguna quest. Revisar alguna que otra guía no te hace menos, en especial considerando que Exile venía con su propia hintbook y editor de personajes de forma legal (?)
PD2: Cuando se me pase lo quemado que me quedó el cerebro tras más de 90 horas jugadas, voy a continuar la historia en el segundo juego. En el fondo, te deja con ganas de más.

author: {'steamid': '76561198865667867', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 17000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12135, 'last_played': 1680329398}
review:
This is so hard to word. If you want the nut shell then here it is. This is my favorite game ever. Now I don't care about graphics or cheap thrills. I only care how well the story pulls me in and the experience as a whole. For a long time my favorite games has been skyrim and then assassins creed primal for when and how they came into my life right when I needed them and changed my life for ever. I played the free demo to Avernum and went to jail. Long story yea but when I was in my cell I had a lot of time to think about what I played and how well it had been put together. It was just someone behind a computer pushing buttons but to me it was a perfect blend of adventure and dare I say poetry. I never experienced this blend and as soon as I got out of jail I bought every game and am still only on the first. This is finding actual treasure. It's like the time I was digging holes as a child and found chicken bones thinking I found dinosaurs (turns out in the 50s my dad killed every chicken on our farm and buried them in a mass grave where I was digging) but this time I actually found the real deal. If you question buying this just play the demo like I did. Imagine this. This is your life
0-------------------------------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------80
You die at 80 and that little plus is a moment in time. We let so many moments go unchecked and don't mind. Most of our life go out the door as sleep and work. Its not big deal to live intentionaly for just a moment and try this game. You may love it or hate it but why not give it a try? If nothing else you are strengthening youre grey matter to try new things despite the self imposed oposition. My god I cant spell but it is my right to contribute a verse when I feel it in me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970169443', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 3843, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 762, 'last_played': 1702354586}
review: I love this game! Great balance of story and action. No giant cut scenes grinding the gameplay to a halt, just great dialog choices.  Freely exploring and uncovering the map is fulfilling and I love how you have the freedom to go anywhere, not just locked into a path from destination to destination. Your movement is fast and there are plenty of towns, so I never found travel tedious, or inventory management a problem. The dungeons are full of tough but fair battles, and great loot. It gets all the things I love about RPGs just right. Although I am not in a hurry to have this game end, I can't wait to try some of the others Spiderweb Software games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198348395457', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1658540340}
review:
This game is an absolute YES.
I was a little esceptic at first because i'm not a huge fan of turn based games on isometric (i prefer those that are from up to down). Because I played Exile 3 and Blades of Exile i had an idea of what to spect with this saga of games.
So even before playing a lot i can tell you:
The Lore is the best Lore i've ever played on a video game. Masterfully crafted and really inmersive. I never played the first Exile or the second, so this game is completly new to me.

Just a couple of minutes playing this game i can see a lot of new additions to the combat and spell mechanics.
From my experience i can 100% say: You can replay this game many times and never get tired. Once you finished the game, you'll desire to play it again with another aproach and other kind of characters (i write this with my experience of Blades of Exile from behind).

If you love turn based games, this one is a MUST HAVE. I wish this game were more popular because is an absolute jewel.

And i will say this anytime i could: if the developer read this review, please upload Blades of Exile to Steam, it's my favorite turn based game ever. The posibility of making your own adventures, opens a huge chance for the community to build great things. Pixel art games are well apreciated on the steam community.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001222484', 'num_games_owned': 404, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2112, 'last_played': 1702874007}
review:
In 2021 this is still better than pretty much every game I've purchased in the last few years. I can't believe that one man, as low-key as he is, can write such incredibly alluring lore to such an in-depth underground world. I would rather read this guy's exposition than George R. R. Martin's. If one can look past the limited graphics, there is an amazing game underneath. The combat it challenging and fun. The character building is familiar and robust. The narrative has branching paths and the writing only gets better the deeper you get. Please give this game a chance if you liked the RPGs from when Bioware wasn't woke and lame, back when Baldur's Gate was capturing our hearts. 
(This game lacks music, which some might not like, but it is incredibly easy to find fantasy themed lists on spotify)

author: {'steamid': '76561198141621687', 'num_games_owned': 1060, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 1327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1327, 'last_played': 1620830790}
review:
Nachdem ich in einem einstigen Insomnia Sale auf GOG netterweise die Geneforge-Reihe gewonnen habe ist Avernum für mich nun der zweite Ausflug in die Spiderweb-Software Reihen, die ja immer durch recht viele Teile und einen gewissen Schwierigkeitsgrad glänzen (der jedoch für einen alten Rollenspielehasen durch besonnenes Voranschreiten in der Spielewelt gut bewältigt werden kann). Nachdem ich Geneforge im Großen und Ganzen einigermaßen passabel fand und mir über Avernum viel Gutes zu Ohren kam, entschied ich mich hier auf Steam die neue Version zu kaufen - auch um einen Vergleich zu dem älteren Design der Geneforge-Titel zu haben.
Nun was soll man sagen, der bereits erwähnte Schiwiergkeitsgrad wurde in der neuen Version wohl abgespeckt. Was ich so gelesen habe, soll man sich in der älteren Version noch mit Hunger und der Option / Notwendigkeit zu Rasten herum geschlagen haben, dieses Feature wurde hier ausgemerzt. Nicht nur das, allem Anschein nach gab es auch in Sachen Levelaufstieg/Skillverteilung einige Neuerungen (die nicht jedem gleichermaßen gefallen haben).
Außerdem habe ich in Beiträgen aufgeschnappt, dass die Gegenstandsauswahl / die Gegnerdrops Änderungen erfahren haben, auch nicht unbedingt zum Besseren / zu mehr Vielfalt hin...
Dies sind Aspekte, die mir unmittelbar ein wenig aufstießen, zumal man in der Spielwelt an die fehlenden Funktionen erinnert wird...direkt in der ersten Stadt gibt es einen Raum, in dem man angeblich bequem und sicher rasten können soll (so der eingeblendete Infotext), dieser Text scheint allerdings ein Relikt aus alten Tagen zu sein, denn eine Rasten-Option ist beim besten Willen nicht zu finden - da nicht vorhanden. Das empfinde ich persönlich als grober Schnitzer, wenn eine Funktion entfernt wird, sollte man auch die Überbleibsel davon aus einem Spiel tilgen, sodass man nicht auf Features hofft, die sich am Ende als entfernt herauskristallisieren...Das war auch der Grund weshalb ich überhaupt anfing nach Unterschieden zu forschen - die mich zugegebenermaßen direkt entmutigten, das Spiel beherzt anzugehen. Am liebsten wäre ich nach der Erkenntnis direkt zur alten Version gewechselt, aber da ich diese nicht besitze und diesen neuen Teil nicht zurückgeben kann, raffte ich mich auf weiterzumachen und zu hoffen, dass es vielleicht doch nicht ganz so dolle stören wird...Das hat es dann auch nur bedingt, da ich den direkten Vergleich ja auch nicht hatte und die alten Features nur vom Hörensagen kenne...
Aber das Spiel als solches entpuppte sich für mich generell als ein sehr sprödes / ödes Abenteuer bei dem ich das Gefühl habe Etappen mühselig abzuarbeiten. Das Gefühl des trockenen Abarbeitens ergibt sich aus der zu Spielen wie Oblivion gegenteiligen Natur der Spielwelt, die sich aus strikten Levelgrenzen und starken Kontrasten der Gegnerstärke zusammensetzt. Und dem Naturell der Items - es gibt eine etappenweise Verbesserung der Gegenstände, wenn du an einem gewissen Punkt / in einem bestimmten Gebiet ankommst, dann wird deine Ausrüstung plötzlich obsolet und die nächsten Waffen / Rüstungen der selben Gattung betreten die Bildfläche, die sich von der alten Ausrüstung zumeist nur durch ein anderes Material auszeichnen, z.B. wechselst du vom Bronze- zum Eisenspeer. Oder von der Ledervariante der Rüstung hin zur Eisenvariante.
Dies ist nahezu die einzige Form der Itemvielfalt, die ich während meiner 20 Stunden Spielzeit zu spüren bekam. Ganz selten findet mal ein magisches Exemplar von Lederstiefeln oder einer Kette, die Werte wie +1 Geschick oder +10% Kälteresistenz spendieren (auf die Seltenheit von magischen Gegenständen wird auch in Dialogen eingegangen). Die Händler haben so gut wie immer 1:1 die selben Waren, und diese sind in den meisten Fällen zwar extremst überteuert, aber dennoch schlechter, als das Equipment, das du bereits hast. Naja ist auch besser so, dass wir das Zeug also nicht unbedingt brauchen, denn das Gold wird man noch dringend für die ebenfalls extremst teuren Zaubersprüche und kaum erschwinglichen Lebenstränke / Energietränke benötigen... Auch hier ist die Auswahl eher bescheiden und auch hier wurde das System im Vergleich zum alten Avernum abgeändert (Alchemie soweit ich weiß abgespeckt).

Wie ihr sehen könnt bin ich über diese Gameplay-Aspekte schon mal so gar nicht begeistert...hier präsentiert sich in anderen Spielen gleich ein viel bemerkenswerterer Item- und Zauberfundus.
Kann das Spiel also wenigstens in anderen Gameplay-Bereichen oder gar in Sachen Story glänzen?
Leider nein. Das Kampfsystem ist ordentlich, aber auch nicht mehr. Ich liebe rundenbasierte Kämpfe, aber bei diesem Kampfsystem kommen keine strategischen Glücksmomente auf, es wirkt sehr einfach gehalten und angestaubt - zweckdienlich, schwerlich mehr als das in meinen Augen.
Dass die Gegner nicht mitleveln und in manchen Regionen so stark sind, dass man sich anfangs niemals dorthin verirren sollte, finde ich grundsätzlich nicht schlecht und etwas was sich einige an Spielen wie (wie oben bereits genannt ) Oblivion oder Skyrim gewünscht hätten...Aber in Kombination mit der mageren Itemauswahl, die man erzwungenermaßen in fest gesetzten Abschnitten für die nächste Variante der selben Sorte austauscht, wirkt das alles sehr rigide und eben so als ob man etwas 'abzuarbeiten' hat. Klar es erfasst einen so manches Erfolgsgefühl wenn man die bösen Oger, die einem anfangs noch in Angst und Schrecken versetzten plötzlich mit neu gewonnener Stärke endlich dem Erdboden gleichmachen kann und so den vollen Umfang seiner Kräftesteigerung realisiert...aber das täuscht nicht über den starren Grundrahmen der Spielewelt und der ihr innewohnenden Mechaniken hinweg.
Auch die freundlichen Charaktere, die sich so in Avernum herumtummeln und mit uns ins Gespräch kommen, wirken leider öde und zum Großteil seelenlos. Sie erzählen ihre eigenen kleinen Geschichten, aber Geschichten, die man im Grunde gar nicht unbedingt hören will, da man ähnliches schon zum tausendsten Mal gehört hat und die Gespräche ohnehin nur in ein und die selbe Richtung verlaufen können. Entweder du nimmst einen Auftrag an und führst ihn dann genau wie vorgeschrieben durch, oder eben nicht. Es gibt keine unterschiedlichen Lösungswege für Quests und keine Gesinnungsfragen. Wenn du deinen Charakter durch individuelle Entscheidungen im Umgang mit Mensch und Monster formen willst, dann bist du bei diesem Spiel ganz schlecht beraten. In der Hinsicht war Geneforge etwas besser. Geneforge hätte ich im Vergleich zu Avernum wohl auch gerade noch so einen Daumen nach oben gegeben, dort fand ich die Story auch ein wenig mitreißender, und man hatte etwas mehr Varianz in der Handhabung von Quests...Bei Avernum kann ich mich leider wirklich nicht dazu durchringen...genauso wenig wie ich mich dazu durchringen kann es zu Ende zu spielen...geschweige denn die nachfolgenden Teile anzugehen...
"Escape from the Pit" hat mir leider schon gereicht um zu wissen, dass ich in diese "Grube" nicht noch einmal geworfen werden möchte...

author: {'steamid': '76561198046618321', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 927, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 927, 'last_played': 1611236131}
review:
This is a Spiderweb Software game, and Spiderweb Software games are all about looking past the surface-level flaws to get to the good stuff at the game's core.

The graphics are basic, the sound design questionable, and the music non-existent. But with a bit of imagination, and guided by the high quality of writing, Avernum is a truly interesting and unique setting that's ripe for exploration.

Exploring the world can feel difficult, at times, due to the levelled world forcing you to poke around until you find somewhere level-appropriate. But once you do, the world's packed with random encounters, towns, dungeons, and so on, so that you'll always be rewarded for exploration.

Getting new loot isn't represented graphically at all, so the impact can often feel small. But the magical items in the game are well-designed to reward the player for obtaining them, be it powerful weapons, or items that let you open up new paths in the overworld and in dungeons. 

There's few real opportunities for you to roleplay your characters, and no companion system beyond your starting party. But the characters you meet are well-written, and at times, provide some great comic relief. 

Avernum is for players who want an old-school RPG, and are willing to accept the game's limitations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059198305', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 8118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5517, 'last_played': 1643488537}
review:
Finished a hard playthrough, completing the three main end game quests. Avernum: Escape from the Pit is a modern remake of Avernum 1 which was itself a remake of Exile. It is an old-school, turned based dungeon crawler with up to a party of 4. I played with a party of Main Tank, Dual Wielder (DPS/off-tank), Priest (primary healer/buffer), Mage (caster with a side in Priest for alternate mass healing)

Pros:
A massive open world to explore.
Quite lengthy.
Very interesting game setting and story imo.
Pretty decent writing for describing NPCs and areas.
Can be quite challenging, with plenty of difficulty battles.

Cons:
Graphics are very dated.
Can be a pain to get started in the early game. While the world is massive, enemies stronger than you are basically can't dodge most of your attacks, do lots of damage to you, get first move and resist most of your damage that you actually manage to land (enemies have quite heavy resist in the game I found) so a lot of the early part of my game was stumbling around trying to figure out where to heck to go at my level. Acid and Lightning damage absolutely wrecks you early game.
There's no way to see enemy stats so you're kind of blind when attacking stuff as you have no idea what type of stats it has or even what level it is; this winds up with quicksaving, getting wrecked, quick loading a lot.
Quests are very simplistic, with no real moral choices. This is a dungeon crawler but would have been nice to have some more meaningful decisions.
Combat can get a little repetitive I guess.
Bit of a nitpick but pathfinding can be a little annoying. It can be difficult to move to certain squares due to the player sprites and characters can swap places with each other but only if you do this yourself so if they don't have a clear path to attack something or move to a place they'll try to take the long route (and potentially run into other enemies doing so).

Dungeons balance tends to be a tad random at times. Some have areas of increasing difficulty, while dungeon bosses can be far more difficulty than other content. Often you'll find yourself having to clear out parts of the dungeon that you can then go looking for other content to gain level before you can tackle the rest. Basically expect to do lots of quicksaving + loading as you explore and do dungeons.

Recommended assuming you can tolerate the 'old-school' graphics and slow turn based gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993278561', 'num_games_owned': 181, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 4229, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3966, 'last_played': 1619464756}
review:
Such a basic game, thou it’s insanely addictive full of content which is worthwhile and every challenge is a joy and rewarding.
You won’t find here beautiful graphics or sounds latest unity engine or whatever no PvP or co-op either.
This is Single player at its best!
This is the top notch at the niche it represents which is Old-school RPG with turn base.
I’m playing this now for the second time to earn all the Steam achievements and still amazed at how much fun this game is and so vast so far 70 hours and still got stuff to do!

author: {'steamid': '76561198157861531', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1603, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1654375765}

author: {'steamid': '76561198052295754', 'num_games_owned': 159, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 3904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3904, 'last_played': 1611388669}
review:
Pozn.: Dohráno za 65 hodin (se splněním všech questů).

Avernum: EftP je první díl trilogie výborných izometrický indie RPG her od vývojáře Jeffa Vogela. Vlastně se jedná už o druhý remake. Struktura her z tohoto universa je docela matoucí a rozebírat to by bylo na dlouho, takže jenom odkážu na [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avernum]wikipedii.[/url]

Když jsem spouštěl Avernum poprvé, ani ve snu by mě nenapadlo, jak moc mě tato jednoduše vypadající hra pohltí a že v ní strávím 65 hodin čistého herního času. Avernum je totiž masivní podzemní jeskyně, kam Impérium, které vládne vnějšímu světu, umisťuje nepohodlné občany - kriminálníky, politické oponenty nebo příslušníky nelidských ras.

Hráč si na začátku vytvoří partu čtyř dobrodruhů. K dispozici je několik předdefinovaných povolání, ale ta za moc nestojí. Lepší je vytvořit pro každého člena družiny nové povolání, což se děje jednoduchým alokováním atributů a skillů. Díky tomu lze sestavit pestré portfolio vlastností tak, aby naše squadra byla konkurenceschopná především vojensky, protože Avernum je RPG zaměřené primárně na boj. Zároveň ale nabízí několik desítek questů a poměrně zajímavý příběh, který má tři různá zakončení. Ta se navzájem nevylučují, takže je možné splnit je všechny. 

V jednoduchosti je síla a Avernum je toho krásným příkladem. Hra možná vypadá prostě, až primitivně, ale právě díky tomu je oproštěna od spousty otravných mechanismů moderních RPG a nabízí neskutečně chytlavý gameplay. Jakmile k Avernu člověk usedne, je těžké se od něj odtrhnout. ;-) Pokud se nenecháte odradit old-school vizuálem, budete bohatě odměněni. Avernum je totiž opravdu prvotřídní RPG.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058459688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 160, 'playtime_forever': 4725, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4725, 'last_played': 1618342715}
review:
[h1]Gameplay: 7/10[/h1]
[h1]Graphics & Sound: 1/10[/h1]
[h1]Narration: 5/10[/h1]

Now, that's an ugly game. Honestly when I started it, I was thinking "here comes a game I'll spend 30+ hours on through the sheer power of Stockholm syndrome, and then will leave a negative review on Steam so that people don't repeat my mistake". Well, I was pleasantly surprised. Not by its appearance - it stays that awful all along - but by the overall role-playing game experience.

✔️ Nice tactical combat, with some area effects, movement abilities, and impairing statuses.
✔️ Interesting class-less character building system. It remains pretty optimal to specialize yourself, but the choices are pretty rich, and cross-specialization is [i]possible[/i] though less efficient.
✔️ A pretty huge dungeon-like structure to explore freely, with a lot of content to interact with, hidden passages, and different ways to move around.

💭 The game's indications of enemy power level are very implicit, which can benefit the immersion, but also creates some frustrating "die & retry" situations.

❌ [b]This game is deeply, terribly, and mind-bogglingly ugly.[/b] This is my main grudge with it. The issue is not even that much about how ugly each individual element is - some graphic elements are ok, others less so - but more about the cohesion of the whole. It looks like different images used in the game have been ordered from various artists, without any effort to make all of them follow a common direction.
❌ This game doesn't have a displayable world map. Or if it does, I haven't found one in 80 hours of play. Seriously, having an accessible overview of the discovered world area would have helped me so many times, this is crazy.
❌ It is sometimes tedious to click on the ground because an enemy prevents you from clicking behind them. The game would probably be a bit more enjoyable if you could only interact with squares, not the enemies on them. The amount of time I spent trying to position an area effect correctly because of that must be crazy.
❌ A lot of elements would benefit from being a bit more explicit, specifically the detail of the character's current damage, resistances, critical chance, etc.
❌ The game has quite a few minor user experience issues I won't detail here.

Overall, despite the heavy negative section, I would recommend this game, since it offers an actually interesting dungeon-exploring experience if you are able to look over its terrible graphics.

author: {'steamid': '76561199051005467', 'num_games_owned': 22, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1617807432}

author: {'steamid': '76561198068798751', 'num_games_owned': 208, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 7781, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7781, 'last_played': 1617550987}
review:
Solid old school RPG with very well-written world and lore. Story is rich but doesn't really have the oh-so-popular (nowadays) choices and branching narratives (which often either flop utterly or only serve as an illusion).
It doesn't hold your hand so expect to find areas you can't beat and things you can't do (yet). This is how these kinda games used to play out and I love it. Gives you a sense of progression.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037308790', 'num_games_owned': 257, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 11427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6586, 'last_played': 1661533206}
review:
What can I say, busy with my second playthrough. The first was many years ago. But this is how games should be made. Obviously the graphics are basic. Or ... less then that actually. Up to the point where I sometimes miss items because I did not see them :D 
But...take a huge world with many cities, caves, dungeons, towers, quests, treasures, mages, monsters, secret passages, a story and...your group of adventurers and you get all the ingredients for a brilliant old school adventure game. Seriously, a lot of companies should cut the crap and make games like this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009506875', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 11602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11600, 'last_played': 1617152630}
review: It took 193 hours, toons around level 35 and it's finished.  Something kept me coming back.  Not many in this genre get it right.  (Baldur's Gate is the standard for me)  This is the second Spiderweb game I've played and finished.  If you are looking for an old school, open ended, detailed game (story wise), this is it.  I started gaming in the 80's so I felt right at home with this.  Plenty of info online to get you through.

author: {'steamid': '76561198340169030', 'num_games_owned': 388, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 859, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 859, 'last_played': 1616409905}
review: well for me its was a shyt experince of a game, you can miss 3/99 times in a row with a 95% chance but dont you worry those enemies with 8% wont miss once cuz the game only has that way to artificially increase the curve of difficulty, the game fells mostly cheap and some times you dont know if the developpers were lazy or incompetent at points,its not soo evident when you play with 4 characters but play with one and it becomes all too evident, at the start you are like:weird my spell miss 5 times in a row with a 95%, but when you get mauled by 8 sith warriors for 20 turns without miss having them 8% hit chance its when you realize that those numbers are there to fool you and nothing else,and when you cap all the resistances to 90% and pretty much go around naked cuz as a paladin weapons are decorative and armour even more soo you wonder why bother, enemies can have nearly 95% res to everything and one two or three inv. stuns & slow on hit but there you are cap to the maximun and praying you dont find a mob of low level undead cuz otherwise all you can do its wach 8 undead permastun and slow you till you die 20 mins latter(that happened to me with 4 (and i was level 42 ffs)

author: {'steamid': '76561198022854959', 'num_games_owned': 792, 'num_reviews': 383, 'playtime_forever': 2523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2523, 'last_played': 1555735975}
review:
I am a huge fan of Spiderweb Software games!

People who love oldschool isometric CRPGs and don´t mind “simple” graphics will love this game.

Avernum: Escape From The Pit is the first instalment of the Avernum trilogy.

Like all Spiderweb Software games the story is deep and meaningful (prepare to read a lot), there are tons of side quests, encounters and dungeons. Decisions you make during your play will influence the ending of the game. 

I needed more than 40 hours to explore the whole map!

I enjoy the turn-based combat. It is challenging (especially on higher difficulties) and “forces” you to use everything you have available (potions, scrolls, magic items, skills). No more hoarding items like other RPGs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101459516', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1821, 'last_played': 1615426889}

review: Probably one of my earliest experiences with a RPG in it's original Exile days, and definately my earliest open world experience. And saying that, getting the remaster was worth the money and I still love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082008298', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 8436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3234, 'last_played': 1672457053}
review:
I gave Avernum a try after playing through Spiderweb's similar Avadon series.  It is a fun and engrossing retro-graphics RPG which will appeal to people who enjoyed the computer RPGs of the 80s and 90s.  Party-building is an important element, and you create your entire party at the beginning of the game rather than building one and finding the rest in game.  

The graphics and sound are all modest, but the gameplay and plot are solid and there are a LOT of quests to do and maps to explore.  Highly recommended to anyone who liked Avadon or enjoyed classic old games like the Ultima series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198438626545', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1148, 'last_played': 1617409920}
review: Jeff Vogel used to make decent games.  The Avernum remake is not a good game, it's save scum trash.  I'm not sure what happened, but character building is  now wonky and doesn't make sense, the displayed hit % are incorrect, and combat is just not fun.  Skip this game, if you really want to play Avernum, go for the original.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025381298', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1156, 'last_played': 1614487153}
review: good game, one I should play more

author: {'steamid': '76561198010147849', 'num_games_owned': 213, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 589, 'last_played': 1655801431}
review: Avernum 1 remaster is a great game worthy of your time and attention if you like deep and story-rich crpgs. It's graphics and sound leave something to be desired, true, but crpgs are essentially about stories and choices, and this game has plenty of both. The combat and progression are simple to understand and use, and they offer a flexible way to develop your characters in any direction you like, whether you want a sword-wielding mage or a spellcasting warrior. Combine that with an open world where you can go in any direction you wish to explore, only to have your ass handed to you if you wander into a nasty encounter that does not scale to your pitiful level, and you have an excellent crpg that may keep you busy longer than many puddle-deep AAA titles. And guess what - there's two more Avernum remastered sequels waiting for you when you are done with this one, so that's awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970550187', 'num_games_owned': 772, 'num_reviews': 188, 'playtime_forever': 3160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1684885195}
review:
An absolutely perfect RPG for anyone looking for an interesting story, simple but meaningful combat and character customization and a clear UI that is easy to navigate. The world is large and interesting with hidden areas, useful loot, fun encounters and combat, and flavorful character progression that you can use to easily build the team you'd like.

Like most Spiderweb Software games, this is a true indie gem and a labor of love. I highly recommend playing the free demo if you are curious, or just buy the full game if this sounds like your bag of holding.

author: {'steamid': '76561198253083496', 'num_games_owned': 245, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 3820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2068, 'last_played': 1709615135}

author: {'steamid': '76561198275305797', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 19215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18815, 'last_played': 1612889131}
review: Super cool and challenging on Torment Difficulty. Main disadvantage I recall - some mobs can't be killed fairly until you get to certain levels. Especially those with magic attack - you often is just one-shot victim. This happens due to characters' resistance is deducted significantly on torment. And due to fact each level gained gives probably more survivability than skills attrs and items altogether. All these mechanics are just lazily blackboxed into the game. Game pushes you to read forums instead of explaining rules by itself.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977708843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1494, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1337, 'last_played': 1612608098}
review: much nostalgia very wow doggo approved

author: {'steamid': '76561198272908267', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 4028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4028, 'last_played': 1570333103}
review:
Quite a charming RPG. I love the worldbuidling and has a wonderful and unique world to explore. I completed all the win conditions and it was a very fun experience. Graphically and gameplay wise it's nothing to write home about, but the gameplay loop, charm and sense of exploration more than makes up for it. Having your party start out as next to nothing and become true heroes in their own right is something many RPGs claim to offer, but the Avernum series really hits that mark.

Jeff Vogel and Spiderweb Software are awesome and are definitely worth a look.

author: {'steamid': '76561198359805547', 'num_games_owned': 159, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 4792, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2603, 'last_played': 1692796721}
review:
Good game but severely lacks creativity and imagination when it comes to the main setting. 
You'd expect a crpg set in an underground world to have lots of mystical weird creatures that looks like a final boss from an JRPG but all you're going to find is your usual bats, spiders, wolves and goblins. The game might as well have been set in the surface. 

Despite all that, good game with good writting, very ''sandboxey'' so you're the one to make your own adventure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045341687', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 3044, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3044, 'last_played': 1611771147}
review:
I like a nice, normal difficulty. Give me a good story and make the combat just interesting enough. The writing is generally good in this game. It's Jeff's strong suit. Game balance is not his strong suit. It's his biggest weakness. Jeff's idea of "casual" difficulty is what most normal people call "teeth grinding eye bleeding" difficulty. The game starts out well enough. But, it doesn't last. After the eastern gallery, Jeff's inability to balance things comes through like the smell of a bloated, dead whale. 

I mean this thing might have been great back in the day when there were less than 1/4th the amount of video games on the market than there are now. 

But, not now when there are so many other things to pick from. And I am not a niche part of his "niche" crowd that'll give him a good review no matter what he does.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081604598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 657, 'last_played': 1526845103}

author: {'steamid': '76561198335048511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 497, 'last_played': 1608786373}
review:
If you love Spiderweb Software's games, you will love this.  If not, than not so much.  It will feel much like the others in the franchise, only the stories seem to differ and even then...  That is not to knock it however, as it is like saying DOOM played exactly like DOOM 2, but if you have played any number of these RPGs, you will know exactly what I am talking about.

That being said, it has tons of content in it.  Lots of places to explore, items to find, use and sell and monsters to vanquish on your journey to find a way out of the pit.  I still find myself enjoying the game, even though it looks and feels like the others.  Keeping what is good and tried and tested is not a bad thing.  If this is your first time definitely give it a go.  But for those who have played the other series... well you already know the deal.  I do recommend the game regardless.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052366023', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1895, 'last_played': 1610217127}
