author: {'steamid': '76561197996935693', 'num_games_owned': 1318, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 4795, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4795, 'last_played': 1556957336}
review:
[h1]Avernum: Escape From the Pit is a CRPG gem![/h1]
[i]tl;dr at the end[/i]

Avernum: Escape From the Pit is probably my favorite gaming surprise of the year. I did not expect to become so engrossed in its world.

Graphically, Avernum has nothing to boast about. IMO, the graphics are pretty bland. However, they are serviceable and I eventually got used to it. 

Gameplay wise, Avernum is pretty good even though it doesn't feel modern - and the UI doesn't help either in that regard. Combat has its quirks, but is satisfying.

Dialogues is where Avernum shines. Almost everything you learn from Avernum, its story, inhabitants, and struggles is through text. Not necessarily from NPCs, but also from the paragraphs that pop up when needed - and as the graphics don't convey much, they appear often.
Every dialogue, every piece of description, every fragment of lore immerse you into Avernum's world.

Soon, I found myself playing it all the time. I have around 80hrs in the game, and I can say it's a blast seeing your party transition from cave-noobs to beloved adventurers among the underground. And I'm overjoyed to know I'm not close to finishing the game!

Recommended to every CRPG fan!

[b][u]tl;dr[/u][/b]
+ Good ol' turn-based combat that is satisfying
+ Engrossing world and story
+ Unique world and setting
+ Great writing!

+/- Pretty old-shool
+/- Can get repeatitive

- Has some quirks in the UI, UX, and quality of life departments
- Serviceable graphics, but nothing great

author: {'steamid': '76561198850324180', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 7362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7362, 'last_played': 1554856352}
review:
Excellent jeu!

J'ai terminé ce jeu quelques mois après avoir traversé la trilogie Avadon. Si l'histoire, l'intrigue et le développement des personnages est beaucoup plus riche dans Avadon, Avernum est un monde ouvert, un jeu centré sur l'exploration, l'expérimentation. Excellent jeu de rôle, où une mécanique à la fois riche et simple se marie très bien avec un monde immense et des quêtes qui permettent à la fois aux personnages de devenir plus puissants et offrent aux joueurs la possibilité d'approfondir le monde d'Avernum et ses habitants.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982913646', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 2120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2116, 'last_played': 1676941965}
review:
This reminds me so much of the golden era of RPG's such as Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale, except that Avernum feels more open-ended than those games. I remember taking the step from Baldur's Gate (which was admittedly linear in an open way) to something like Morrowind, where the player's only limitation in the world is their temporary weakness. Avernum provides the best of both worlds, where you are thrust into a world and allowed to plunge into its depths at your own risk, all while retaining the moral ambiguity of handling quests and events as either a paragon of righteousness or a self-serving scoundrel -- and everything in between. Or not at all. You're allowed to walk away from quests and roam freely.

I only want to give passive mention to the graphics and production values because, yes, they are noticeably inferior to most other games on the market, but after about fifteen minutes of gameplay it's the last thing on your mind. The game plays like a novel, where you see X wall with Y door and are given a detailed description of the location, and once you get into the game your imagination runs wild.

But you HAVE to enjoy reading in games, because almost everything warrants paragraph upon paragraph of description. However, even though I'm not a fan of walls of text, in Spiderweb's games such a mechanic doesn't bother me at all.

Overall I highly recommend this game. It truly is greater than the sum of its parts, and is far more immersive and enjoyable than the majority of AAA titles overcrowding the market. You can throw hundreds of millions of dollars at a game and still not achieve the immersion and interest that fills each crevice in Avernum.

author: {'steamid': '76561198871434117', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 6710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4463, 'last_played': 1560573531}
review:
If you've never played a game that looks like this before - give it a chance. I've played a lot of console JRPGs of every type and a couple Skyrim games but alway steered clear from games that seemed a bit too much like D&D b/c they seemed too "involved" and I thought if I didn't plan properly I'd reach a point where I couldn't pass b/c I didn't plan properly. This game is not that (on normal difficulty) - I trust your team members to do what you set them out to do and though I've died A LOT; I still love it. Also you actually have to read and pay attention to the lengthy (but well written) story to know what to do next.
9/10: Deducted b/c it's not entirely clear when you've completed a mission and the description may not tell you who to go back to actually finish it. It is possible do the mission of "kill 10 spiders", not know that I've killed all the spiders and never get the extra bonus for finishing it because I never talked to that person again. Also just a bit more clarity overall would have been nice - you can only see what level your spells are at from the keyboard-shortcut screen and a lot of things having to do with resistances/battle stats are never fully explained.
Build; Customx4
- Duel Wield Tank w/full tank armor on hand
- Black Mage
- Priest (automatically lends itself to wearing heavy armor which is nice)
- Warrior Mage w/Bow, Sword, Shield and Priest Magic (no points added to sword skill)

author: {'steamid': '76561197972394679', 'num_games_owned': 933, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 3512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3512, 'last_played': 1550030114}
review:
Disclaimer: You must be literate to play this game.

My first Spiderweb game and I'm not sure how I never heard of these. The graphics and animations were clunky at first, but once you adjust, an RPG experience with very little excess fat remains. The writing is solid, there are no cheap tricks to extend  playtime, there is minimal rambling fluff text, and they didn't waste money hiring actors to read those lines out loud. A hidden gem, for sure, easily on par with an Arcanum or Fallout 1/2 in HD.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043840291', 'num_games_owned': 602, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 891, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 872, 'last_played': 1555055494}
review:
This RPG is good. 

When you look at indie RPG you often expect them to be too complicated for their own good, too verbose, too complex. And often this complexity doesn't bring anything to the table. Avernum is still relatively complex: you control a party of 4 characters (unless you want a challenge and go with fewer characters), each has main stats, skills, perks, a lot of inventory slots. Your party travels the underground land of Avernum doing tasks, getting famous, encountering several end-game quest lines. The world is truly open in a good way, sometimes you're limited by your fame, knowledge of spells, skills like lockpicking, specific quests - but for the most part, you can easily get somewhere where you will be obliterated. In this regard the game is similar to classic RPGs like Might & Magic or Wizardry - it's all about exploration and combat. Unlike modern RPGs Avernum has some great dungeons that are not just battle arenas, they often include secret passages and different approaches to encounters.

The story is relatively simple but well presented. You rarely do any serious decisions through dialogue and your stats only affect combat and exploration. It's all user-friendly and the game doesn't want you to trap yourself with bad decisions. E.g. exploration skills are counted for the whole party: it doesn't matter if you have one guy with lockpicking 4 or 4 people with a single skillpoint in lockpicking. Hybrid classes (e.g. archer and fighter) do not work that well but are still viable on Normal.

Spiderweb games are unique in that they don't feel like indie. They don't try to be nostalgic, or old-school, or very unique. They feel like a normal RPG with outdated graphics and no voice acting or anything. But they also lack a lot of boring stuff you're used to in modern games. Try it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052078433', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 4873, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4510, 'last_played': 1527436138}
review:
The Exile games have always been full of fond memories. 
My brother and I found a demo copy of the original by chance and succedeed with a few tries to make it work on a modern pc. What we found was a very old-style rpg with mechanics smooth as sandpaper but with lots of complexity and charm. I was hooked instantly.
Despite the carpal-tunnel inducing controls and the primitive (but charming) graphics it had lots of positives:
the combat was pure tactical bliss, the leveling/equipment system was complex with recipes hidden through the world, the puzzles were intriguing and often required taking notes, and the story and setting were (and still are) pretty set apart compared to most fantasy games.

BUT that was Exile.... not Avernum.
Avernum is the third remake of "Exile: Escape from the Pit" from 1995. If you can find a copy of the original game you will likely find it nearly unplayable but, disregarding nostalgia, it was a pretty innovative game for the old-school tactical rpg genre. 

Avernum has only the plot and setting left from the original game.
The graphics have been slightly improved, and thankfully so have been the controls, but sadly Jeff Vogel decided that the leveling and combat/magic system was not worth the time so it was cut and simplified to the point it leaves some holes in some items and quests.

It feels like a weird hybrid made to make some bucks with low effort: 
it's not not old-school anymore but it's not really modern.
It still plays and looks like an old game but has nothing left that an old-school junkie can find enjoyable.

At this price you can find more entertaining and more deserving projects.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084270662', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 8146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5150, 'last_played': 1694384095}
review:
Всегда был поклонником продуктов Spiderweb Software. Играть в эту серию игр начал еще с попавшейся на диске с shareware играми Exile 1, которую до сих пор вспоминаю с удовольствием. Потом был ремейк Avernum 1, который я также проходил, но многие аспекты мне там не нравились (очень решали магии 3го уровня, которые раскидали по всем подземельям и квестам в единственном экземпляре). И наконец, выпущена новый ремейк под аналогичным именем: Avernum: Escape from the Pit (также назывался и первый Exile). 
По сравнению с Exile, игра намного сложнее с точки зрения боев, менее свободная в плане магии, но, безусловно, намного удобнее в плане играбельности. В этом ремейке Jeff немного отошел от так не понравившейся мне концепции магий 3го уровня: здесь они полезны (некоторые - очень полезны, некоторые вообще не улучшаются), но не так принципиально важны. В каждом подземелье есть сложный босс, а иногда и несколько, каждый из которых чаще всего имеет при себе уникальный предмет обмундирования.

Рекомендую эту игру всем любителям жанра RPG, кому важна в первую очередь глубина сюжета, а не графика, кто готов читать тонны текста на английском языке (без этого никак). Сюжет и квесты (за исключением нескольких) прямолинейны и не представляют никакой свободы выбора, хотя в последнее время мне такой вариант нравится больше. Можно спокойно играть без подсказок, не боясь, что в другом месте за того или иного монстра или предмет заплатят больше. Кому нравится разветвленный сюжет - рекомендую попробовать другой продукт этой компании - Geneforge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087441896', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 12469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12319, 'last_played': 1551776626}
review:
I have some nice memories playint the Exile trilogy back in the '90s. I wasn't disappointed in the remake of the remake. 

Pros: excellent story; a huge and unique world, which differs well enough from the boring D&D cliché worlds; lots of content was added to the original story and world with the remakes; junk bag (I never seen this concept before in other RPGs, if Jeff invented it, he should certainly register a patent :-); no performance problems, ever.
Cons: the rule system is a big oversimplified (i.e. melee weapons come in two varieties; ranged weapons in only two categories); not so well documented (what are the maximum values of various stats?); some content present in the original Exile was half-rewritten (i.e. Tower of Sulfras golem giving misleading tip on Sulfras' hoard).

author: {'steamid': '76561197990030738', 'num_games_owned': 2041, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2313, 'last_played': 1546668948}
review:
I went into this game completely without expectations. Before playing this, I had never heard of Spiderweb Software or any of their games. I now own their entire catalogue. The graphics are simple and the gameplay can be a bit clunky (especially when trying to aim AoE spells), but where the game shines is the worldbuilding and lore. I wouldn't say that the story itself is that great, the three "great quests" are actually pretty simple story-wise, but what sucked me in were all the little things along the way. The writing is just great.

Also, this is the first game I've played where I've had a giant spider flirt with me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034960142', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 34075, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33070, 'last_played': 1517857186}
review:
30 plus hours of gameplay is an understatement. This game world is very fleshed out and you will actually want to talk to all npcs. One of my favorite RPGS of all time. 
10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198084158211', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2740, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2572, 'last_played': 1553436726}
review:
Pořádné RPG, které se výborně hraje, když se tomu dá pár hodin na usazení. Souboje jsou tahové, takže je možné si vše dobře rozmyslet. Pokud někomu nevadí old-school vzhled a mechanismy hry určitě nad tím stráví spoustu hodin. Doporučuji.
8,5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198001905880', 'num_games_owned': 1193, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 4084, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4022, 'last_played': 1614689908}
review:
I grew up with consoles, so I missed out on the Planescapes and BGs of the PC world. Unsurprisingly, Spiderweb Software wasn't a name I was familiar with, but I gather they've had a pretty strong cult following for several decades. Having played this remake of a remake, I can fully understand why. What Avernum lacks in cutting-edge graphics, it makes up for in spades elsewhere.

Thankfully, this is a game that plays its hand fairly early, and you'll be able to decide whether it's for you inside two hours. The tutorial dungeon gives you an overview of the combat system, skill tree and general environment before flinging you out into the subterranean world that is Avernum. Here be tunnels, 'cities', lizard people, a sallow-skinned populace, dragons, and an environment that oozes atmosphere. This is the strongest point of Avernum; Jeff Vogel and his crew have created a world that feels simultaneously sterile and thriving, lived-in and desolate, depressing yet hopeful. There are areas of population, but mostly innumerable crevasses and passageways untamed by humanity. An entire subterranean ecosystem and corresponding lifestyle has been devised, with a little magical assistance. Law and order tenuously holds...in some regions. And multiple factions war amongst themselves on several fronts. It's quite a unique and compelling environment to be stuck in, despite seeming visually bland at first glance.

The writing is excellent, particularly considering the small team. Flavour-text is plentiful, and most important NPCs will respond to the events of the gaming world as you complete quests and move the plot forward. Each little town and freehold has a purpose and speciality, making them feel distinct - often aided by the quests they give out. Fort Draco works iron like no other town, but has a major issue with oversized arachnids; several southern towns have soldiers to spare, but little iron and the market is priced accordingly. Speaking of quests, there's over 80 in the game, and they're varied - ranging from fetching materials to banishing mighty demons. Many of them give you autonomy in the method of completion, and just deciding to kill everyone involved can occasionally be an option. If I have one major criticism of this game, it's that it does get quite overwhelming at points; you can amass an absurd number of quests at once if you're not clearing them regularly, and that can certainly add a bit of fatigue as you try to keep track of things.

The graphics are rudimentary, and evidently not at the coalface of development for obvious reasons...this doesn't especially detract from the game, and when paired with a clean interface is occasionally quite charming in an old-school way. All information is clearly conveyed, at any rate, which is vital in a game like this. The sound design is interesting; Vogel is on record as disliking ambient music in his games, so Avernum is largely comprised of a strong and wide range of sound effects that bolster the overall texture and atmosphere. The battle system is also pretty basic, albeit with increasing subtlety as the game marches on and you accrue more skills - I'm not too fussed about battles in a game like this where the focus is on the writing and game world, but you will be doing a lot of fighting, so the system will be important to most. To that end, I'd steer clear of Torment difficulty on a first pass through the game, since I hear that combat gets supremely frustrating unless you know the game mechanics intimately.

Mostly though, Avernum captured my rapt attention through the richly-detailed environment, oddly compelling plot and unique feel. Like Trails in the Sky, it's a game that rides a strong script into an unusual setting and doesn't look back. There are weak points, and it won't be for everyone, but Avernum is honestly one of the most absorbing games I've played this year, and left a strong impression. Awesome achievement from a small team.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043764153', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1678089705}
review: Classic dungeon crawl style game. It's not as pretty as many modern RPGs nor are there are any fancy animations, but it's got some fun level design. Although this says I've only got about 3 hours of playing the game, I've played and won the game before. Enjoyed it so much that I bought it again on Steam later.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041222458', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 6013, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1670, 'last_played': 1547239284}
review: Avernum is one of the most rewarding RPGs i've ever played (and i've been playing RPGs for 35 years, starting with Might & Magic on the C64 to The Witcher 3 and Mass Effect in PC). The graphics and animations are basic, but the sense of exploration, the story and writing, and the challenging battles (in hard settings), gave me a truly joyful experience. I read that the game was made almost by a single person, and this was an exceptional work. Obviously it lacks of fancy graphics and sound, but you forget about it very fast, enjoying the exploration of the world and the huge amount of content. This is a "hard" game, that doesn't take you by the hand, and you need to remember things and take notes to enjoy it completely. Totally recommended for true RPG lovers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074105445', 'num_games_owned': 164, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2714, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2423, 'last_played': 1548103819}
review: Really nice oldschool RPG with amazing storyline and universe. I love it, i just wish to carry our characters to 2nd and 3rd games aswell but still amazing rework to that my childhoods old games. Good job keep it up. After finish 1st game if u start 2nd right after it might be a bit boring but i find the rule to play like finish 1 game then wait a year so i forget and miss the mechanics so 2nd game will not be boring and it will be exciting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032736750', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 43302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20287, 'last_played': 1545194778}
review:
I have one word that sums up my experience with the first installment in the "Avernum" series and that word is "YES". I mean like hell fucking YES. I suggest not ruining this opportunity for yourself, don't overthink things or talk yourself out of buying the game. Dont "not" buy the game because one disgruntled pansy wrote an EmoRageFit review because he prefers his hardcore RPG's to be a bit on the lighter side, more like a graphic novella with cutesy characters and lots of awkward dialogue. Don't let the primitive graphics fool you, this game is "massive" and immersive, you truly feel like your in a series of massive caves, deep bellow the earths surface.

I actually played the second Avadon game which despite the fact that I am a glutton for punishment, left a bad taste in my mouth when I played through it on the 2nd to highest difficulty. I felt at the time like that game was impossibly difficult at the higher settings but It had been just long enough for me to have forgotten how that game had made me literally throw things and I am glad my memory was short because this game is amazing !!!

I have been playing CRPG's since they first existed,  I played The Oregon Trail on the Apple 2 and have played hundreds if not a thousand RPG's since then and "Avernum Escape From The Pit" had me thinking about getting off work and putting my hands all over it, more than my GF who was waiting at home for me to put my hands all over her .... its just that good.

If you want a cutesy JRPG that plays more like a graphic novel and holds your hand, dick, vag, and your eyelids open for you then this game is not for you. If your the type of person who considered FFX1 & FFX2 to be the toughest games ever, this games definitely not for you, go watch some more Anime and/or hentai and forget this game exists. If you want to be punished, then get smarter, then be punished again , then get even smarter and better equipped, this game is definitely for you.

I just picked up 4,5,6 for under 2$ a piece and that is hundreds of quality hours for under 5 bucks and that is very rare. It is clear that the dev's who made this game, understand how to get the old guard all hot and bothered so don't let the effort go unnoticed  and just pick the game up because I dare you to find more enjoyment for your buck

author: {'steamid': '76561198147574830', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 5413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5368, 'last_played': 1543003133}
review:
Я очень редко пишу негативные обзоры на игры, которые мне не понравились. Все же на вкус и цвет — и все фломастеры разные. Но бывают случаи, когда мое возмущение от того или иного продукта просто не сдержать. Тем более, когда у игры более 90% положительных обзоров в Steam, пестрящих фразы «для тех, кто любит классические Fallout, Baldur’s Gate и Morrowind». 

[i]Итак, Avernum: Escape from the Pit — «шедевр» г-на Джефа Вогеля — является ремейком Avernum 2000 года, который в свою очередь, является ремейком Exile I: Escape from the Pit, игры аж 1995 года. И игра практически не изменилась, претерпев два переиздания. Она из того времени, когда RPG являлись тем, что сейчас принято называть dungeon crawler. Т.е. игры, сконцентрированные на исследовании и боях. При этом художественная часть была элементом второго план, либо игнорировалась.[/i] 

[h1]Нарратив[/h1]
Миром правит злая-презлая Империя (а-ля Советский Союз). Всех преступников, инакомыслящих, геев(!!!), несправедливо обвиненных ссылают в Авернум, суровый подземный мир (а-ля Гулаг), из которого практически невозможно выбраться. Не повезло и группе наших протагонистов. Тут стоит отметить, что идея вполне себе интересная: подземный мир, который получает тепло от непосредственной близости к ядру планеты, а свет — от магически изобретенных люминесцентных грибов, питается искусственно выведенными грибами-растениями, чахлым скотом и ящерицами-переростками.
Но проблема кроется в том, что лор подается скупой парой строчек. Информации о народах, населяющих Авернум, катастрофически мало. К примеру, вы не узнаете ничего о гуманоидных ящерах, кроме того, [spoiler]что их не встретить на поверхности, а в Авернум их изгнали из родного мира собратья за их воинственность и кровожадность.[/spoiler] За интересной задумкой стоит простенькая реализация «чтобы был фон». В то время как Pillars of Eternity обвиняют в излишней многословности лора, в Avernum его недостает. 

Ко всему прочему испытываешь лудонарративный диссонанс. Исходя из сюжета, в Авернум сослали ооочень много людей. Но при этом города состоят из 5-6 домов (а то и трех) и едва-едва двух десятков жителей. В тавернах вечно заняты комнаты. Ассортимент магазинов не обновляется. Персонаж описывается длинноволосым и нечесаным, а на аватарке стриженный под ноль мужик. Одетому в белое монаху досталась моделька мага в зеленом. Дракон с размахом крыльев в 10 метров слегка повыше ваших персонажей. И таких мелочей, рушащих восприятие игры, целая куча.

Диалоги — короткие и обрубленные — малоинформативны, дают слабое представление о мире игры и персонажах. Отсюда — никакого сопереживания и эмоционального вовлечения. Нет глубоких и разветвленных квестов. Все просто: надо найти книгу -> нашел книгу -> отдал. При этом даже не включается окно диалога, а всплывает сообщение: «npc вас благодарит».

Где-то год назад, Джеф Вогель выдал аж две статьи, где разбирал как плохо с нарративом в Pillars of Eternity. Как ему было скучно читать диалоги, и он под конец прокликивал их, о том, что выборы бессмысленны. Весь этот «глубокий» анализ приправлялся россказнями о том, какой он молодец, и что Avernum (правда, речь шла о второй части, но не суть) подвергся тотальному редактированию. Но вместо того, чтобы облагородить текст — где-то раскрыть персонажей, дать героям мотивацию, дать выбор — текст сокращали.
Параллельно с прохождением Avernum я проходил Diablo 3. И знаете, там диалоги и лор, были куда осмысленнее(!!! [i]это фиаско[/i]). Все эти фразы компаньонов с твоим персонажем превращали их из анимированных болванчиков в личности.

[h1]Геймплей[/h1]
В принципе, основное ядро игры сделано неплохо. Но как говорится, дьявол кроется в деталях. Как было сказано выше, исследование и бой — основные действия игры. Путешествовать по подземному миру достаточно интересно. Свернув с дороги, вы, скорее всего, наткнетесь на секрет/событие, а может даже на ценный лут. Но, к сожалению, мир огромен до неприличия. Кроме того, игра вынуждает вас заниматься бэктрекингом. Так что все эти путешествия очень быстро приедаются.

Поначалу я хотел похвалить сражения в игре. Действительно, пошаговая боевая система всегда приятна. Но знаете, когда под конец тебя пичкают сражениями типа «убей тридцать врагов, пройди по подземелью с постоянно спаунящимися солдатами», начинаешь уставать.

При этом боевая система очень простецкая, и заточена под min-max статов. Хотите нагибать — качайте нужный для вашего класса стат до упора.
Забудьте об отыгрыше. Игра никак не реагирует на ваши действия. Непонятно зачем нужен бесполезный параметр репутации. Непонятно почему игра не реагирует, когда я обносил целые магазины на глазах у хозяина.
Вариативности практически нет. А где она есть — опять же не важно, что вы выберите. Я всю игру помогал агенту Империи, и все равно мне пришлось свергать тиранию. 

[h1]Визуальная часть[/h1]
Ну, игра поддерживает высокое разрешение…К сожалению, это единственное хорошее, что можно сказать о ее визуальном аспекте. 
Достаточно открыть скриншоты и убедиться, что уровень графики остался в нулевых. Современные инди-RPG, несмотря на изометрический вид, стараются облагородить свою графику детализацией, освещением (Pillars of Eternity, Divinity: Original Sin, Wastelands 2 и прочее). Игры с меньшим бюджетом превращают пиксель-арт в мини шедевры. Интересный дизайн тоже не про Avernum. Если вы видели один город, считайте, видели их все. Несколько типов ландшафта — это все на что хватило Spiderweb.
Но самый кошмар — это модели персонажей и врагов. Разнообразия нет вообще. Как вы себе представляете сражение с суровым последним боссом? А как вам, что у него моделька как у алхимика или торговца из города? Эта же модель использована для магов вражеских и дружественных. Одни и те же модели монстров, раскрашенные в разные цвета — это все разнообразие.

[h1]Аудио часть[/h1]
С этим пунктом еще беднее. Скудный набор звуков и полтора трека. Яркий показатель того, что не вписалось в бюджет.

[h1]Технологическая часть[/h1]
С технологической точки зрения игра просто кошмар.
Годы опыта, скопившегося за время существования игровой индустрии, Spiderweb старательно игнорируют.
Отсутствие банальной подсветки предметов, игра превращается в настоящий пиксельхантинг. И чтобы узнать, лежит ли что-нибудь на земле, нужно открывать инвентарь. Существует шанс, что находясь в достаточном отдалении от предмета, вы его пропустите. 
Для часто используемых скиллов выделили всего четыре слота. При условии, что приходится подстраиваться под ситуацию и вместо, скажем, огня, атаковать молниями, т.к. у противников иммунитет к огненным атакам.
Герои всегда ходят гуськом. Отряд нельзя разделить. Т.е. заранее выбрать более выгодные позиции для персонажей невозможно.

[h1]Выводы[/h1]
Я не вижу, где здесь ремейк:
[list]
[*]Морально устаревшие решения в геймдизайне.
[*]Визуальная часть и интерфейс — кровавые слезы. Единственное старание — прикрутили разрешение на широкоформатники.
[*]Художественная часть — будто проба пера подростка. Как утверждает Джеф, была проведена редакторская работа и «многабукоф» было выброшено на помойку. Вполне возможно были выкинуты куски лорной информации. Лучше бы сократили размер игрового мира и свели бэктрекинг к минимуму.
[*]Несбалансированная и маловариативная боевая система.
[/list]
Это не игра. [b]Это труп игры, воскрешенный злобным некромантом Вогелем.[/b]
В Escape from the Pit я провел 90 часов (70 часов на полное прохождение + 20 часов пришлось выкинуть из-за запоротой прокачки) и я хотел бы злиться на игру и ее создателя… Но я опустошен. От прохождения я не испытал ни радости, ни облегчения. Как бы сказала моя Охотница на демонов из Diablo:
[quote] «Не хватает ненависти!»[/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561197970185005', 'num_games_owned': 269, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1079, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1708435334}

author: {'steamid': '76561198267409502', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 587, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 587, 'last_played': 1541850775}
review:
BOF...bof...pour résumer ca manque d'originalité

difficile d'évaluer ce jeu...bon c'est pas beau et ca manque de bruitages mais bon ce n'est pas ce qui me gene le plus...
mais bon c'est austère quand même, le jeu souffre de la compraison avec baldur s gate 2 avec sa musique et ses bruitages et ces personnages charismatiques.
disons que voila, ca manque franchement d'originaliité :
l'idée que tout se passe dans une immense caverne (mais alors vraiment immense) est plutot bonne en soi...les gens se nourrissent de champignons et ont édifié des forts,  ils vivent pauvrement et ont la peau blanchatre...(sans que ca se voit graphiquement sur les skins des personnages...)

MAIS
 les quêtes ne suivent pas derrière...j'ai joué 9-10 heures et pour l'instant  j'ai chassé du bandit, de la chauve souris et des humanoides-qui-détestent l'humanité aidés par des gobelins...le genre de trucs que tout amateur de rpg a déjà fait dix fois...
les donjons sont pas mal designés avec un ou deux passages secrets qui cassent l'impression de porte-monstre-tresor...mais ils ne s'illustrent pas non plus (monstres rencontrés dans les donjons par exemple : des rats géants ,eh oui ENCORE...) 
le pire c'est les boss où on a un faux semblant de dialogue : par exemple le sombre pretre se tient devant moi et me défie, je llui dis assez le sang a suffisamment coulé, esperant que des choix vont s'ouvrir (va t il falloir le corrompre ? va t il me proposer une quete ?) et ben non on enchaine sur le combat sans que ca ait de conséquences
c'est comme le systeme de combat : c'est vu et revu... les mages ont des sorts type boule de feu et invocation de monstres , les pretres des sorts de heal et de boost...
les 3-4 villes  que j'ai visité se ressemblent : un magasin, une auberge, un office et un tableau de quêtes...Elles manquent d'un axe majeur, de quelque chose qui les différencie l'une de l'autre et leur donne une personnalité
en somme l'écriture des quêtes n'est pas spécialement profonde, les personnages secondaires sont plutot bien décrits mais ca manque de vraies grosses discussions (notamment les compagnons), il ya la quantité mais ca manque de profondeur...

globalement le jeu n'est pas mauvais c'est juste qu'il souffre de la comparaison avec baldur s gate 1 et 2, fallout 1 et 2 (qui proposait un setting vraiment original malgré sa laideur), voire meme plus récemment avec morrowind (pour les champignons et l'immensité du monde)
là je ne sais pas ce qu'apporte de nouveau avernum escape from the pit...apres j'ai payé deux euros ...a ce niveau c'est un bon rapport qualité-prix...

author: {'steamid': '76561198024893178', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 41387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5382, 'last_played': 1673130911}
review:
The game is a turn based party quest game, somewhat like Baldur's Gate but with much poorer graphics and with no character - to charcter interaction.

That said. it's a lot of fun and inexpensive.  I would almost say it's a must play.  The worls is huge, open ended, and can be quite difficult, especially if you role play a little and don't cookie cutter your skill points as your characters level.  It doesn't hold your hand!   You will run into situations that you just can't handle until later, others that you can but you have to try a few times to get things to turn out right.

If you like turn based rpgs and don't mind crude graphics, this is a stellar game.  About the best you can get from an indie group.   There is a lot of reading in the game, and you need to pay attention, but if you like rpgs and don't like readings what planet are you from?    Just my 2c, to each their own.

This is not the original series; this is a remake. I'm not saying that it's bad but I have a strong preference for the first trilogy, the original from the very early 2000s. 

Not sure if this is allowed here but the original games can be found on GOG.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999479652', 'num_games_owned': 444, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 5607, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5236, 'last_played': 1530262857}
review:
Genuine mix of all what an excuisite RPG game should have: story, battle system, level-up system, inventory, quests, puzzles...
Farming is possible, but hgh levels won't guarantee a win in every battle. Often the player must understand the current story and follow the quest with wits. This game does not forgive dumb decisions easily, but will reward you with a story that is quite unique and interesting, if you will chew through the quests to the 2nd half of the game. After that, you won't be able to stop, you will crave for more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198314000103', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2125, 'last_played': 1704422243}
review:
Avernum:  Escape From the Pit is an amazing role-playing game.  I never had the opportunity to play the original Exile trilogy, the Avernum trilogy, or its three sequels.  This reboot is my first experience and I can finally see why so many people were drawn to this series of games.

The simplicity is its draw.  Well, for me anyway.  An easy to use interface with simple world design has allowed for a game with Elder Scrolls level amounts of detail.  Now I don't consider this a drawback, but some will, the game is incredibly text heavy.  To me, this is a scratch for an old nostalgia itch.

The graphics, while nothing to write home about, are good in their own right.  They fill the niche that the game has created.  You don't have thousands of character portraits, but you do have the ability to design your stats, abilties, skills, etc. to your specification.  And if you just want to start they have classes.  And if you really, really, want to start, the premade starting party is ready to go for a good, balanced game!

You can even use the editor and add spells, abilties, and whatnot without ruining your game which is a nice touch.  I have only invested about nineteen hours so far but plan on investing many, many more for the quest system is awesome.  From the main story (which has several trees of completion), to the side quests, and job boards, there is a ton of stuff to do.

There are fun, random encounters and just getting experience and collecting spells is enjoyable.  Speaking of spells, the system for learning and leveling spells is very reminiscent of AD&D in that one can only learn so much from a teacher.  One must discover the spells "out in the wild" or from Arcane Altars if they wish to improve beyond the basics!

There are plenty of items from swords and spears to magic scrolls and wands to the mundane like pipes and towels.  

If you love RPGs you love this game.  If your older and grew up on AD&D I think this game will suck you in!  I know for me it did because I bought all three and its "sister" games, the Avadon series.

I give this game a 10/10.  I have yet to find even minor quibbles to gripe over because the game even comes with a wonderful built-in instruction guide that literally has everything about the game you need answered!

author: {'steamid': '76561198069159152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2402, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1537389184}
review:
This is an old-school RPG. Graphics are similar to games such as Baldur's Gate. Combat system is decent. Plot is engaging, and the quests are intriguing...

Still, I would probably get it on discount. Or consider the Trilogy bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990295933', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 585, 'last_played': 1534875487}
review: While the games playstile is a classic RPG experience, I enjoy playing on high difficulties in games of this style and find that the Hard and Torment Difficulties are not worth playing. The game combat system and items are in no way balanced with any regard to character progression, stats, and item availability, making the choices for playstyle in order to beat the game on high difficulties is completely limited to choosing from an extrememly limited few options of character builds. Beating the game becomes much of a dice roll on high levels and since the game does not give the player specific numerical breakdowns for abilities, the player is left in a circumstance to beat the game in a way that resembles trial and error in combination with dice rolls in order to discover which upgrade paths are most useful and whether or not the next big baddy is permanently unbeatable based on a player's build. Unfortunately for me, because the abilitiy to beat Avernume: Escape From the Pit on higher difficulties relies on tactless interactions, I must say that I do not recommend this game to anyone other than players who enjoy playing games on default and easy difficulties.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049532860', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2922, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2922, 'last_played': 1534536017}
review:
48 hours I sank into this game...

This game is very solid; no game-effecting bugs, and a very fluid progression. At every turn in the game you will face challenges. I played my playthrough on normal difficulty; I ended it by killing the final demon. Tried killing the emperor, but there was no way my setup was going to do it.

Tips for new players: Get a character to dispel barriers. That is singlehandedly the most crucial thing I would say to succeed in this game. There are so many barriers and so few crystals... If you choose not to get a dispel barriers, you sure better hold on to the piercing crystals with every precaution available to only do ones that impact your quests.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040637577', 'num_games_owned': 364, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 3223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3223, 'last_played': 1527762267}
review:
[h1]General Overview (7.8)[/h1]
An old but still very playable game that scores above average to good on every category. Graphics scored lowest due to it being an old game, but still within acceptable parameters. Worth the low price in tenfold!

[b]1. Gameplay (8)[/b]
Already a pretty old RPG, but one that I even recently started playing again because it is just made so well. The gameplay is fun and flexible, you can decide what kind of party you will and if you're good enough at it, you can make it work no matter how you want it. A full healer party? Been there, done that!

[b]2. Content (8)[/b]
The content is more than one would think at first impression. It is a very big world and becoming a thief will make some NPCs attack you, instead of giving you a quest. A big part of the game changes when you change your choices, which is very unique for an old game like this!

[b]3. Graphics (6)[/b]
Although the graphics and some interfaces have been redone entirely from scratch in the later years, it is still an old game and so it has, in comparison to now, shitty graphics. But it is certainly very playable after the graphics updates the creator of this game has done a few years after the release.

[b]4. Comparisons (8)[/b]
In comparison to other RPGs, I got to say this was certainly one of the better ones. Nowadays, of course, better ones came out. But back in the day, this was absolutely unique. The graphics and interface update is a nice bonus and makes this still a game in the top tier of its kind!

[b]5. Price (9)[/b]
There are no microtransactions in the game which makes the buy price the only money you can and will spend on it. Certainly worth it, as the low price can provide for a way higher number of hours!

[b]Bugs (-0)[/b]
Not specifically bugs, but some standard hotkeys do not work since they weren't "standard" back in the day. But one can easily get used to this after an hour or two.

[b]Grading[/b]

        [td]Average[/td]

author: {'steamid': '76561198120400500', 'num_games_owned': 91, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 5509, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5509, 'last_played': 1529823675}
review:
[h1]The original Avernum, remastered![/h1]

[i]Avernum: Escape from the Pit[/i] is actually (deep breath) a slightly remastered version of the dev's own remake of one of his earliest games.  Over twenty years ago, he released [i]Exile:  Escape from the Pit.[/i]  Two more games were released until he decided to remake the trilogy as Avernum.  Then, he added a second trilogy to the story of the Avernum series.  I played the second trilogy's games when they came out and liked them, but had yet to get around to the original three.

So, time to finish the series, if a bit backwards.  Hee hee.

Spiderweb Software's games are decidedly old-school, with isometric graphics, but a [b]DEEP[/b] and detailed storyline.  Tons of quests big and small, and a novel's worth of dialogue and descriptions.

You have some, but not a lot of chances to choose what happens instead of a simple scripted event.  Several dialogue trees merely serve to funnel you back to a mini-boss fight.  Other dialogue trees bury what you need to unlock or finish a quest with an NPC.  You may have to systematically work through the choices to progress in a quest.

The 90+ hours I put in covered most of the quests, and attempting all three of the possible final quests.  You can do all three in the same game.  Plus, of course, lots of reloads because characters perished.  (Only complete party death is fatal to a game.  Reach a town with even one live character, and the rest are revitalized.  I usually reloaded if just one died.)

You have near-total customization of your party.  Unlike later games, your party must be all humans.  You can choose from one of several looks for your characters, though.  While you are given the choice of "classes," really those are just starting builds.  As you level up, you gain points to put in stats and skills and traits that you can allocate almost however you wish.

Of course, given that there are mage and priest spells in the game, you will probably create one of each magic school.  Pure warriors are not left out, however.  As you level up in weapon skills, those unlock battle discplines for extra power or a spell-like effect.

There's very little hand-holding in these games, aside from a quick tutorial at the start.  And once you leave the town you start in, there's very little guidance on what areas are good for what levels.  You'll be getting quests in nearby areas that are too strong for you for a good while.

Fortunately, there are some in-game helps.  There's a journal of quests and a way to save pages of information beyond what the quest journal gives you, and a list of the undroppable quest items you accumulate.  You have a game world map with not only a "you are here" marker but also points of interest you find and important quest locations marked.  You also have a mini-map that is automapped as you explore.

Game action is turn-based, but not tediously so.  If you are not in combat, just clicking on a distant tile that is not too far away will send you walking.  

Enemies are numerous but generally finite, no random encounters.  Do most of the quests, though, and you will max out your point potential.  This only becomes frustrating when trying the final quests and you'd rather have a couple more levels to survive.  (One of the three final quests is [b]BRUTAL[/b] and made me ragequit the final battle after a few attempts.

Gold is limited and best reserved for purchasing spells.  Note that you can only gain two levels in a spell or skill from a trainer, but that there is often a book out somewhere for a third level.  You are much better off raiding and trading for other useful items such as potions.

However, inventory management is excellent.  Part of your inventory is devoted to a bottomless "junk" bag that you can just toss in anything you are going to sell and then sell all in just one click.  This is a feature I do not recall being in the second trilogy.

Each character's individual inventory is limited, but you can dive into inventory even in battle to use an item.  There is also a strength-based encumbrance limit on equipment; too heavy and it will slow you down.  This is only a factor in the early game.

Movement seems to be the only thing that is mouse-only.  Everything else has keyboard shortcuts.


Without playing the original Avernum game, it's tough to tell what might have been added, outside of perhaps the junk bag.  Some details do feel like a bit of seeding for future games, either planned when first created or additions in the remaster.

It is a delight to see how the land evolves over the series.  If you've played one and liked that game, you'll enjoy any of the others.

review: Enjoyed the world allot in this game, stuff is hidden everywhere so I felt I was always rewarded for exploring. Old school in the sense you got to pay attention to what the quest givers tell you or you'll end up lost like me a lot of times. If you enjoy Isometric games worth a look.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066185939', 'num_games_owned': 289, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 6455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6452, 'last_played': 1531942453}
review:
Avernum: Escape From the Pit is no doubt one of the best RPGs you can purchase on Steam. The reasons for that are many--The game provides a lot of content in the form of sidequests and exploration. The game also has lotsof customization for characters and parties. Finally, and best of all, the game has multiple endgame scenarios, meaning you could complete one and call it a playthrough or go for the trifecta and complete all three of them.


Overall, I would recommend Avernum: Escape from the Pit to any RPG player.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968210099', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 231, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1519320023}

author: {'steamid': '76561198050434471', 'num_games_owned': 589, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 1489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1313, 'last_played': 1627732144}
review:
I was in one of the minor forts in south. My destination was the Castle, to seek an audiance with the king. Then I came up with a vendor who was selling cheap wine. Another vendor in a  mining city to the very north wanted to purchase cheap wine. So I decided to sail to the north, with the boat I purchased. On the road, curiosity beat me and I took land on an island. There was a cave full of spell casting evil spiders. The boss of the cave was a hivemind spider, and I killed it in a very hard fight. Then I came up with another cave which is full of spiders, again. But those huge spiders were friendly, all named Spider. One of them found my char "cute" and wanted to mate with me... I politely refused. It kissed my leg and run away.

Avernum is a decent RPG. Like all other Spiderweb Software games. Graphics and sounds are limited. Gameplay is ok. But it has tons of fun and has its moments as the story above. If you want to play a retro style RPG, just give it a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107826712', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 192, 'last_played': 1523368562}

Graphic: 7
old school but charming and with its own style

Sound: 6
nothing exceptional, but not bad, sound effects not good instead 

Gameplay: 8
rock solid, lot of choice story wise, lot of customization combat wise

Overall: 7

author: {'steamid': '76561198049391660', 'num_games_owned': 1165, 'num_reviews': 185, 'playtime_forever': 4715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4645, 'last_played': 1523637379}
review:
(Yes, I'm one of these guys who never finished the original Exile.)

A proper (second remake of an) epic-scale RPG, with great party management, well-balanced tactical battles, and lots of quests and exploration. The graphics are pretty bland; however in these sort of games it's the writing and the world building that really counts, and in Avernum both are top notch!

If you're unsure whether it is your cup of tea or not, Spiderweb Software's website has huge playable demos of their games that will help you make up your mind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100828814', 'num_games_owned': 626, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 2703, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2703, 'last_played': 1522120788}
review:
Отличный представитель рпг-жанра
Плюсы
-Огромный мир, полный секретов
-Интересная пошаговая боевка
-Неплохой, хотя и простенький сюжет
-Обилие побочный квестов
-Атмосферность
-На самой высокой сложности игра заиграет новыми красками
Минусы
-Нет музыки
-Нет графония (если это кому-то важно) 
-Боевка к концу игры немного надоедает
В общем и целом неплохая рпг, в самый раз для любителей олдскула

author: {'steamid': '76561198025816757', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 17254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 161, 'last_played': 1569626726}
review:
So the Avernum series have been among my favorite games for literally decades at this point, but they really, really aren't for everyone. Please go to Spiderweb's site and play the demo if you aren't sure. That's what it's there for.
That being said, if you like sprawling narratives that encourage you to wander off instead of dealing with the main quests (there are three!), sneaky dungeons, seriously solid worldbuilding, weird political shenanigans centered around freedom as a response to imprisonment (which makes sense in context I swear) and don't care about soundtracks, this may in fact be the game for you! (There's a demo! It's huge! It's free!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198052227203', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 807, 'last_played': 1693295207}
review: I was without computer for a bit of time, so i started playing this game with a friend like when i was 12ys old. Now i'm 31. The emotions, the attenction to detail, the old-school-rpg feelings that i got from this title were incredible. I started taking notes written by hand. One of the few games that made me think that proving the same feelings of marvel & discoveries, fears & exploration of when i was young & ignorant about fantasy & rpg is still possible. Really beatiful game, reccomended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998033326', 'num_games_owned': 62, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 7000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5894, 'last_played': 1704595004}

author: {'steamid': '76561198134098779', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 4040, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3863, 'last_played': 1610860089}
review:
9/10. 60 hours first playthrough. Wow what a good game. Felt like I was playing something similar to Fallout 1-2 but with way more exploration options. Sometimes I would find myself off on some cave system I discovered, completely forgetting about what it was I set out to do and I didn't care I wanted to know how deep the caves went lol. 

Combat system is pretty unbalanced, with magic being head and shoulders above the rest, followed by DW melee, and archery last. Its also an odd system, where you can attack even if you have 1 AP left, though it costs 9 to perform a spell/attack. Then you can't move after you attack so melee is really punished. But its forgiveable because you are so immeresed. If combat was better It would be 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197970326656', 'num_games_owned': 926, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 4283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4283, 'last_played': 1519315770}
review:
Where did 70 hours of my life go?

This game is perfect for you if you like to:
- Optimize you party for hours
- Scour the world for items/quests/secrets
- Like combat driven turn-based RPGs
- Do not care too much for choices/story
- Like a grim world

author: {'steamid': '76561198068594364', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 5070, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5070, 'last_played': 1445034356}
review:
Top Spiel. Man sieht es an meiner Spielzeit. Ich habe es nur einmal gespielt und der Wiederspielwert ist aus meiner Sicht auch nicht so groß, aber die Stimmung, die im Spiel vermittelt wird, ist wirklich top. Ich will hier nicht Spoilern, aber die Atmosphäre ist wirklich bedrückend und man spürt teilweise die Verzweifelung der Einwohner. Wie mit so einfachen Mitteln, etwas so gut in Szene gesetzt werden kann, dass ist für mich immer wieder faszinierend. 

Man darf bei dem Spiel übrigens keine ausgefeilten Spielmechaniken erwarten. Es ist ein altes Spiel und das merkt man auch, aber wenn man sich darauf einlässt, bekommt man ein Spiel, dass einem viele Stunden Spaß beschert. Es hat mich vom Grafikstil auch ständig an Ultima Online erinnert. Damals mit dem 2D Client. Der 3D Client war ja Grottenhässlich.

In dem Sinne. Wer es für 5 Euro im Sale bekommt, der bekommt ein solides altes RPG mit einer stimmungsvollen Atmosphäre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068089729', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 21661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15400, 'last_played': 1500337426}
review: great old fashioned adventure game

author: {'steamid': '76561197978194801', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2185, 'last_played': 1519240846}
review:
Pros:
[list]
[*] Huge world
[*] Combat is interesting
[*] A lot of stuff to explore. There's a ton of hidden caves, fortresses and dungeons.
[*] Oldschool quests: No quest markers telling you where to go exactly (though for quests where you have to go into dungeons etc. it's marked on the world map)
[*] 6 games in the series, if you like this one there's 5 more
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*] The graphics are really bad
[*] There is almost no sound whatsoever, there's 2-3 seconds of music when entering an area and there's some minor sounds playing in combat when you hit someone or get hit
[*] The enemy models are not very varied, almost always they are just recolored versions of other enemies: Ogre mages for example look exactly like the other ogres but cyan
[/list]

It's pretty cheap (especially when on sale), if you like RPGs then get it, otherwise stay away.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095061072', 'num_games_owned': 270, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 2779, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1491, 'last_played': 1521834734}

author: {'steamid': '76561197978382371', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 6505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 979, 'last_played': 1518493348}
review:
Overall impressions: This is a large-scale fantasy RPG with turn-based combat. It's reminiscent of tabletop RPGs, and the game has an elaborate and unique setting. The game is heavy on exploration, dungeon crawling, quests, and building up your party of four characters. Graphics are basic, rather like a simplified version of the original Fallout game; they're more suggestive props than a serious attempt to render the world of Avernum.

What I liked:
+The game is built from the ground up to be flexible and nonlinear. You go where you want to go, you do what you want to do, and you develop your characters how you want to develop them. There are different three main quests; you don't have to do them, you don't have to do them in a set order, and many of the steps provide alternate approaches. While spellcasters and dual-wielding fighters tend to out-perform most other classes, it's quite possible to beat the game with all kinds of different party builds.
+The game scales very nicely as you level up; big boss fights can remain challenging up to and even beyond level 30. There's a nice variety of items as you build up your party, allowing you to tailor your characters' gear and skills to specific tasks and roles. 
+The writing and the concept of the setting are both excellent, and there are a lot of little details that the developers have thrown in. The world of Avernum is packed with places to explore, people to meet and talk to, and enemies to slay. 

What I didn't like: This is mostly nitpicking.
-Sometimes it could be difficult to see some of the items littering a floor, because they don't stand out well.
-Many major quests depend on you noticing tiny features on the screen such as buttons that open secret doors. Missing these buttons required me to do a considerable amount of back-tracking. Eventually, I simply looked up each dungeon online after I finished it to ensure that I hadn't missed something important. 
-A few character features either don't work at all, or make so little difference that they're a waste. The Challenger trait, for example, is supposed to draw enemies' attentions toward a character, but they seemed just as happy to go after others. 

Overall, I'd highly recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989051249', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 166, 'playtime_forever': 7473, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4584, 'last_played': 1520006755}

author: {'steamid': '76561198355158382', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 6720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5568, 'last_played': 1706402220}
review:
When I first played this game (note: the exile verison, not avernum or the remastered), I was quite young and due to one circumstance or another, I never got to play it in its entirety. Fast forward to now, years on, I had long lost forgotten the title of the game and every so often I had remembered the interesting isometric, turn-based game that had filled my childhood with wonders. 

And then about a week ago, I found it. It was in my cart faster than you can say Avernum.

This game is clearly not a game about graphics. If you are big on story driven games, there's a chance you'll enjoy this one.  The controls aren't the most intuitive, and the game feels like it's from the 90s however in my opinion, that's just part of the charm. Though of course, I could be biased because I've been playing the game nonstop since I bought it a week ago.

For me, it's mostly the feeling of fulfilment and satisfaction I've gotten out of following the story, making some hard choices (since there are a few to make - questing is quite intricate in some cases) and deciding what kind of path I want my characters to take. You can choose a standard party of four - a warrior, dex class, healer and mage.. or you can be a badass and play with four priests. In the end you can build your character however you like, which is something I really enjoyed playing around with.

It's a must play if you're into oldschool rpgs.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968480281', 'num_games_owned': 527, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 6668, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6668, 'last_played': 1519457886}
review:
C'est moche mais tres bien quand meme. Pour les fans de RPG surtout.
J'ai bien aimé l'histoire/ le lore, plutot original.
Petit souci dans le systeme de combat: certaines cases (derriere un personnage un peu grand par exemple) sont incliquables. On a pas de preview quand on donne un ordre, si bien que parfois vos perso font n'importe quoi...
J'ai aussi été un petit peu décu par l'arbre des competence trop simpliste. On se spécialise dans seulement 2 types d'armes de melés (et encore ca se croise), 2 type d'arme a distance (et encore ca se croise), et la magie magicien ou pretre, mais tout ca se croise plus ou moins... j'vous ai dit que ca se croisait beaucoup ?
Le jeu a des arcs longs, et des courts, mais ca change rien en fait. Un moment j'avais en ma possession un arc long qui faisait plus de dommage que mon arc court, mais ce dernier valait plus cher que le long... pour quelle raison ? De plus il n'y a aucun inconvenient a choisir l'arc long plutot que le court... étrange.
Mais j'ai quand meme kiffé. 

Le jeu se prete bien au dual screen: le jeu sur l'écran principal et un documentaire/le JT/ une vidéo youtube sur le deuxieme ecran ! Ca m'a permi de rattraper mon retard sur les video que j'avais a regarder.

Dans la plupart des RPG auxquels j'ai joué, les jeux deviennent trop facile avec le temps. Y'a un palier plus ou moins haut au-dessus duquel le jeu devient facile (et souvent chiant) et ce peu importe le niveau de difficulte. Pour Avernum je l'ai mis en mode difficile, et ils se sont pas foutu de moi ! j'en ai pas mal chié tout du long... jusqu'a la fin. Le niveau de difficulte est TRES bien dosé. Bref, j'ai mis le jeu en dur, j'ai eu ce que je voulais tout du long, pas juste les 10 premiers niveaux.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009319688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 10192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9829, 'last_played': 1518146367}
review:
Purchased the game in 2015 and finally got around to finishing in 2018 on my 3rd attempt.  Now feel I am in a good position toprovide some thoughts.  

Basic graphics but story holds it together and keeps you engaged.  Text heavy and suggest increasing this in the options to large.  No voice and limited sound affects.  Open world does give you the option to go anywhere and it is far from a linear experience.  Buying a boat really opens up the map and you will find a need to uncover as much of the map as possible.  

Turn based combat is simple in its structure and spells and disciplines, provides a huge number of tactical options with your playthrough.  Add in potions, buffs and enchanted weapons and there is plently of variety.  Combat can be slow initially until spells etc are bought, made available later in the game.   

Quests do not hold your hand.  They can be cryptic and you need to take note of NPC dialogs / clues.  Some items can also be given to more than 1 person for varying results.  It is recommended to 'record' any dialog containing clues using the record function.  Saves having to find and speak to the NPC again.

Overall provides 50+ hours of entertainment but longer to obtain the acheivements.   

It is a retro style game which will discount many players, but it makes up for it in many other ways.  Value for money is good against expected playtime and a strong storyline to support which is often lacking in modern RPG's.

review:
Old school RPG, turn-based combat, yes, it's coming back to be trending... But this one IS old-school, as part of a somehow renewed version (still very old looking though), of the first opus from the original Exile serie, of the 90s.

Despite dated graphism, all the rest, be it writing, difficulty, choices, immense exploration, and a unique world, makes it a must-have for any RPG fan.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980935229', 'num_games_owned': 108, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3516, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3516, 'last_played': 1514275622}
review: Great isometric RPG that brings back memories of Baldur's Gate. The graphics are outdated but in my humble opinion do the game justices. From sprawling under ground caves (truly the whole game is in a cave) to large castles I rarely felt that areas looked alike. Combat is fun and engaging while the stats are simple, they offer enough diversity to create fun characters. I plan on buy many more spiderweb games after this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024806632', 'num_games_owned': 379, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 626, 'last_played': 1336892400}
review: The Avernum series is a remastering of the Exile series. Avernum: Escape from the Pit itself is actually a remastering of Avernum I. The Exile series originally had 3 games, not counting Blades of Exile. My first experience with Exile was actually Exile III: Ruined World. I found a demo of the game on a Mac Addict CD. I immediately fell in love with the game. I had, up to that point, never really liked turn based RPGs. Exile III changed all of that for me. The amount of thought and effort that Jeff Vogel put into the stories of these games is incredible. After completing Exile III numerous times, I had to have the rest of the series. The 3 orginals, Exile: Escape from the Pit, Exile II: Crystal souls, and Exile III: Ruined world, have in my opinion stood up to the test of time. I really must say that I prefer the originals. But these latest remasters have brought new life to the games that may have otherwise have faded into oblivion. Prepare for countless hours of adventuring, and see how your choices can affect the outcome of the game. I cannot recommend this game enough, and hope you enjoy it as much as I have.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074556259', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 4128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3967, 'last_played': 1486415374}
review:
I started playing this series back when this series was called "Exile."

It spoiled me on RPGs forever.  I've spent the rest of my life looking for western RPGs with as much story, and few annoyances, as Spiderweb's.  Nearly every RPG series (minus Avadon) that Spiderweb has produced has been gold.

This is a reboot of the original, Exile: Escape from the Pit, and while I prefer the old magic system, this is an extremely good reboot.  The game boasts a ton of story, and a very open world.  The graphics are a huge improvement over the old version, even if they don't keep up with more modern games.  In a world of pixel graphic hype, this shouldn't deter anyone.  There is substantially more content here than a great many, much more expensive games.

I very strongly suggest getting both this one, and the updated Crystal Souls game.

Feels like the dev is cranking out game after game after game going for a rabid fanboi base, as another reviewer stated, and I 100% agree.

This game, unfortunately does not seem to have either."

author: {'steamid': '76561198046407276', 'num_games_owned': 6089, 'num_reviews': 233, 'playtime_forever': 14367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13584, 'last_played': 1651987078}
review:
[h1]A game that doesn't hold your hand![/h1]

This is an old school Computer Roleplaying game. I played the old Exile Series as the game still was shareware, and the upgrade only served to make this game a bit more apealing to new players. The developer also created a newer Stats/Skill/Trait interface which makes the game a lot more accessible and the choices a lot easier. Keep in mind, that level only plays a secondary role in this game, they only serve to power your skills, and though it's good to have experts in your group some skills are working for the group as a whole - that said, I resent experts and prefer a group of all hybrids (Arcane Priest, Divine Mage, Holy Lancer and/or Paladin)

Yes, you can customize your classes too, which is a good thing. Also choose your traits wisely when you play this game, almost everything in this game has limits, the amount of gold you can get is one example, or the traits you may chose, or your skillpoints, Javelins, Potions and such - all and everything is precious in avernum which makes the story even more believable. Also the devs put in here an option to remove unneccesary clutter (the trash-bag)... All in all if you compare this to Exile or Genforge the devs put a lot of love in their revival.

[Table]
[tr][th]Category[/th][th]Score[/th][th]Notes[/th][/tr]
[tr][td]Graphics[/td][td]7[/td][td]Compared to the old Exile the graphics have been boosted. Nonetheless, they are still spartan compared to other games. But as with all classical RPG games, graphics isn't everything.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Sound[/td][td]6[/td][td]Don't expect too much sound in those games, you will have strange noises in the big cave that Avernum is, but not so much as a soundtrack or continous music playing. But actually the howling wind, the strange noises of some alien critters is much more than you need for atmosphere.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Story[/td][td]9[/td][td]Why a solid 9? Play the game, immerse yourself in one of the best indie storylines. There are really a lot of quests, challenging or overwhelming some. And the story where you chose to either plot revenge upon the empire, or try to settle in somehow.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Character Dev.[/td][td]7[/td][td]This game offers enough freedom to create your own characters and you can develop them around specialities, or just spread them as your fancy strikes. Also you need to plan ahead, don't waste resources like potions or mana on critters that are just trash mobs for your level, but use the lowest and most effective ways to dispose of them.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Playability[/td][td]8[/td][td]Easy to learn, yet hard to master. This game doesn't hold your hands and you actually can die pretty much, pretty early in the game. Safe often, Quicksafe and Autosafe is included in the game.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Value for Money[/td][td]8[/td][td]As with almost all games that orient themselves on old-school gaming this game offers dozens and dozens of gaming hours, you can pretty much spent a hundred hours in this game and still have not all achievements, all quests solved or even found.[/td][/tr]
[tr][th]Overall[/th][td]7.5 ~ 8[/td][td]*[/td][/tr][/table]

[h1]Recommended[/h1]

It's a simple decission, this game offers a lot in gaming hours, a good playability and challenging quests are another thing that work for the game. This game is worth it's money - even more so if you get it in a sale. This game is for fans of the genre and hardcore RPG gamers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046231199', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3049, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3049, 'last_played': 1502600530}

author: {'steamid': '76561198023289778', 'num_games_owned': 737, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 3626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3115, 'last_played': 1702426792}
review:
This game, and it's previous editions (this is the 3rd remake) holds a very special place in my heart.

Great story and world. You're trapped deep underground by the evil empire above, idk why but I love the concept.

The turn based combat holds up very well, and character skill development works well allowing for unique builds.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023738989', 'num_games_owned': 1597, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2734, 'last_played': 1436844978}
review: I originally played this game way back in the late '90s when it was called "Exile" and released for classic Mac (I was using a Performa 6220CD at the time, maxed out with a whopping 64mb of RAM and 1gb hd!). It still holds just as much charm as it did then, simply updated for modern systems. Infinite choices, infinite ways to play! Explore, adventure, and most of all, have fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198008670396', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 14945, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2178, 'last_played': 1662777736}

author: {'steamid': '76561197974300154', 'num_games_owned': 997, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 986, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 981, 'last_played': 1529801638}
review:
I'll be perfectly honest here: the first time I was introduced to this game, it was in the late 90s, early 2000s under the name "Exile: Escape from the Pit". This is the third incarnation of the same story. If you've played Exile, or the earlier version of Avernum, you know what you're getting into, and you're walking the same steps you have before. This is the same story that they've been telling for decades now.

Even so, it is still worth a play. The new mechanics and polished visuals make it feel like a new beast. The world is expansive, with plenty to see and do. The characters are likeable and sympathetic. There is very little to not love about it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061373274', 'num_games_owned': 248, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 10000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3166, 'last_played': 1681850942}
review:
To start off, I started playing the Avernum series in the early 2000s, around late middle/early high school. Having started at that age, the games had a pretty big effect on me, and I credit them quite a bit with making me interested both in games in general, and also in writing, which I'm now pursuing as a career.

I bought EFTP after much debate because I love the games, but I was not a big fan of the gameplay in 4-6, and had only ever played the first Geneforge. I don't honestly recall if I finished Avernum 4-6, to be honest. But I finally got the itch again and went ahead and bought this version, partially because I didn't want to keep bothering Jeff for game codes every few years lmao. That, and I've decided to subject my friends to some tabletop campaigns in Avernum, and I can record this version more easily for my notes.

I was very pleased with the update. No, it doesn't add a whole lot of extra content, and I'm mixed on some combat changes (WHY DOES HIGH LEVEL SMITE NOT TARGET MULTIPLE THINGS? DOES IT DO EXTRA DAMAGE TO DEMONS ANYMORE? WHY ME? WHERE DID BEAST CEREMONY GO?? but alternatively: HASTE TARGETS EVERYONE! CONE ATTACKS/AOES! FUCK YEAH). 

But as for being in the spirit of the original? Very much so. [i]Very much so.[/i] The nostalgia alone was worth it.

So I'd argue that, if you're just getting into the series, returning from a long absence, or just really fucking love the games, EFTP is certainly worth the money. The last time I played the originals (on Windows 7, I think?) I did have some issues, so having them updated was definitely appreciated.

Overall, I most definitely enjoyed my return to underground Australia, and am looking forward to 3's update in 2018. 

Also, buy Crystal Souls, because that game's my favorite of the three and boy howdy am I enjoying the shit out of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198163070712', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 4434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1755, 'last_played': 1513805108}
